Originally from Holmdel Township, Kim holds a Bachelor of Arts in Management Information Systems from Brooklyn College and an MBA from Indiana Wesleyan University. Kim has experience working in public library systems and non-profit organizations, and brings a broad range of experience, training, and knowledge in management, resource allocation, operations, policy development, and programs with a special emphasis in technology.

astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate planet with more than twice the gravity of Earth last week, researchers are pushing that factor into the mix. Water is one thing – a world with twice the gravity of Earth means twice the pull.
Present-day life owes a lot to the constant gravitational push and pull through its pesky oceans, keeping the planet tilted on its axis and influencing global weather patterns. A world with twice the gravity could get hit with twice the bombardment of water vapour, snow, hail and sand. Even inside the fracture zones and crustal faults, the weight of a twice-Earth-size world would introduce more water and gases than could be contained within a planet of Earth’s size.

Twenty Palaces series follows a magical detective agency that hires ordinary people. One of the Agency's field officers Ray Lilly is given a strange painting that very, very strangely comes to life with pulsing energy. He follows it to a break-in at the famous Parker Gallery, that just happens to have a rather valuable painting identical to the one he just had handed to him by the Agency.
Now Warner Parker, who happens to be, the brother of the infamous Harry Parker, is dead. Warner is the son of the worlds most famed magical living artist, Harry. Michael Walker and Patrick Swain are petitioners in the case, brought on behalf of a class of Mississippi inmates who challenged the three-drug plan that Mississippi had come up with about a decade ago after decades of botched executions.
Those original lethal injection procedures involved either just one drug or a combination of several, including the now-discredited barbiturates sodium pentobarbitol and phenergan, also known as promethazine.
Walker and Swain filed their complaint on June 20, 2017, a little more than a year after Mississippi adopted new procedures on Oct. 5, 2016.
The two challenged Mississippi’s choice of three drugs – midazolam, vecuronium bromide and potassium chloride – saying it presented a risk of cruel and unusual punishment.

. People don’t want the burden of hunting for information in a lot of misaddressed and poorly addressed envelopes.
Before you start the process of addressing the envelope and putting it in the mail, you must decide who you are sending the letter to. If it is a letter that needs to go to a group or department within a corporation, you must conduct some research so that you know how the company is configured and how to address the letter to the appropriate receiver.
If you are writing to a small organization, local businessmen or professionals, you can simply gather the name, company title and address for your recipient. If you are uncertain of the company’s layout or don’t have the means or the time to check it out, you can take a more general approach by using the recipient’s full name.

The letter also was published on Philip Roth's website.
I jokingly suggested "flamewar" for the power dynamic, and I'm sure you'll agree Wikipedia nickname is conducing to a more even playing field.
Collective intelligence, authorship, co-creation, participatory media and the democratization of cultural production are just a few driving conditions to the Wikipedia media system. For more detail, see David White's paper "Life after Wikipedia (for Academic Art Professionals)"

yield a pit of problems for those who made fools of themselves for all the world to see. The assault on our privacy legislation in so many countries though, probably rates as the nastiest demerit of all.

Future Parlays are an innovative technology, developed by the 888sport betting app, which allow punters to choose their own multi-event composition when they've made a future bet or double chance bet on the outcome of a single game. Other types of parlays can be done as well, but Future Parlays allow a higher level of customization - and danger - than the more traditional parlays.
Future Parlay bettors can, as the name implies, speculate in the future about how the final score of a game or a series of games will play out. For the example above, this first entry speculates that the Los Angeles Rams will beat the New England Patriots by a "one or more field goals" final score

The Narromine Garden Club have gifted their annual donation to local organisation the Narromine Volunteer Rescue Association (VRA).
The club gathered at the Narromine VRA headquarters on December 5 to hand over a cheque for almost $1000.

VRA treasurer Jhanette Brown explained that the Narromine Garden Club funds are often directed towards items the budget can't otherwise cover.
"It does make a big difference to what we can do with the things that are unbudgeted, particularly more people are travelling so we get a lot of people having to travel to Sydney to the Children's hospital, so the amount might seem like nothing but it can make a difference," Mrs Brown said.

Thomas Jefferson wrote about Revere in his 1821 autobiography, the only full account of this event he had: "On the first day of April, 1775, the election of officers [for the Massachusetts Bay colony] was closed, and the Congress met the same day, and continued to the fifth, when the spirited and intelligent Mr. Revere was chosen Major of the company that was afterwards called Minutemen."
After the battles on Lexington and Concord, Revere spurred a horse at midnight through the moonlight towards Boston. He carried a summons from his local commander in Waitesborough (now Watertown), ordering Minutemen to arms and for the countryside to gather at the meeting-house in the morning. professionals identify the potential impact of the options they have with a task. The diagram shows the consequences of a decision – the probability of the decisions' outcomes, and the costs and benefits associated with each outcome.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to evaluate the impact of potential business choices on a business’s profitability.
The roots of the tree are the important assumptions made for a task – errors or wrong behaviour at the root are irreversible and can have a major impact on profitability.
The branches of the tree represent possible choices and their impact on profitability – a decision can either increase or decrease profitability.
Like a treasure hunt, decision trees are a great way to understand the impact of a decision on your future.
Decision Trees help you ...
A decision tree helps you to make more logical decisions by making your own assumptions explicit. This is because the decision tree simply records the logic of your decision.

prepared by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) Ames, Iowa Water Science Center, is intended to help guide the development and conservation of water resources in Marcellus Shale gas development. The report provides estimates of the average water consumption by the natural gas industry during the period of 2000-2011, based upon applicable water use permits and production levels. The water-use estimates from this time period are the most complete estimates of actual water use currently available for the full range of the Marcellus Shale gas resource in both West Virginia and Pennsylvania. This report is the first of its kind at this scale.
The report also provides estimates of the total water volume consumed by the top producing values in the Marcellus Shale gas resource. Both reports correct for the fact that natural gas currently produced from this resource is composed primarily of methane (40 to 99 percent of the total) and requires less water than conventional

an interstellar object passing close to the sun.Olixar / Shutterstock
An interstellar object called 'Oumuamua has perplexed astronomers since October 19, 2017 -- the night they discovered it.
'Oumuamua was first detected by scientists at the MIT-affiliated Panoramic Survey Telescope And Rapid Response System in Hawaii. It was already on its way out of the solar system, making it the first-ever interstellar object to be discovered in the sky.
The object was observed for only about two weeks as it left our solar system, but during that time scientists identified some strange things about 'Oumuamua.
In the roughly one-year since astronomers announced the object (which means "A Gift from the Clans" in Hawaiian), these enigmas continue.
In particular, the object'

noise floor is about -98 dB, so you lose one decibel using electronically-shaded (or acoustically-shaded) windows and 10 dB with these labs," says Daniel Croitoru, senior project leader.
A major problem with noisy equipment is machining a feature with potential acoustic problems into a part using conventional noise-suppressing methods such as water-filled chambers. The noise is captured inside the fluid and masks the noise from some intended sensor, raising its noise floor.
A traditional way to ignore noise is to delay it in time by moving the sensor beyond the wanted frequency range. A reverse approach is taking current measurements immediately, and filtering out noise later. Measurements directly coupled to delay-free sensors are then more accurate, with their error ranges decreasing in proportion to the length of the delay. However, delay-free sensors tend to be larger, more complex and

can no longer be based on the experience and intuition of the board. "Everyone" can gain access to all data and use it as a basis for decision-making. But the decision-maker must not neglect intuition
The intuition of experienced employees can certainly be wrong, and numerous decisions are also made using human intuition. But officials also made the wrong decisions in the past based on comparison, tabular analysis and so on. Intuition should never be viewed with skepticism and treated with mistrust. That is what the author of "Progress in the Scientific Management Era" wrote more than 70 years ago. According to the author, intuition is nothing more than the ability to compare the relevant information at a glance.

At the height of the Democratic presidential primaries, the state GOP successfully petitioned the United States Supreme Court to suspend Pennsylvania’s law giving presidential candidates automatic inclusion on the general election ballot if they get the most votes in a primary.
The law, signed into law by Gov. Ed Rendell in 2005, was intended to make the process easier and faster, saving millions of dollars in the process, but the suit argued otherwise. Last March, the U.S. Supreme Court agreed with the GOP, vacating an earlier ruling by Judge Paul Diamond in Federal District Court in Philadelphia.

Of course, though the U.S. military appears to have captured the the head of an insurgent organization, having laid waste to his network certainly hasn't degraded the overall capability of the militant factions or insurgent groups. In fact, these forces actually have their largest enemy, the United States, corralling their forces into smaller units whose capabilities have actually increased.
The splitting their forces into smaller groups in fact allows the insurgents and militants take greater risks and do more damage. Thus, such tactics as the siege of Samarra's Golden Mosque have the potential to severely degrade the militant factions' capabilities over time (perhaps as they continue unchanged for a year, or two). The 900 km-long TurkStream pipeline runs from Russia to Bulgaria and Turkey and across the Black Sea to Turkey and Turkey’s Marmara Sea coast. Part of the stream operates at a pressure of 480kPa for gas intended for Turkey and 320kPa for the supply of north-east Italy and South East Europe, with the potential to increase capacity to 800kPa.
The extension of TurkStream can allow the natural gas to reach Europe without Russian hub infrastructure. The pipeline can dispense a significant volume of gas from Russia to Turkey of about 15 billion cubic meters per year.

was mapped by surveying with chains and theodolites [Wernicke and Burgert, 1992]. In the early 1900s, the completion of the transcontinental railroad and the resulting influx of Westerners made demand for reliable tractability a national concern. Because of railroads, the United States had started to split into two opposite but reassuring halves: measured sections to the east, agricultural expansion to the west. As the frontier moved west, elevated and connected Midwest towns boomed [for the railroad industry and vice versa]. This resulted in differing sets of imperatives of the surveying institutions of the east and west.
The surveying system predominant during the early days of the United States mostly concerned itself with the East Coast territory. The railroad revolution and western expansion necessitated changes in surveying tools and processes that enabled a changing nation to move west and defend weak

supernovas, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident planets and stripping the whole system of its atmosphere before the unfortunate star even collapses and disappears.
Sometimes that explosion originates at the merging of two or more pairs of close, orbiting compact stars, called white dwarfs. Under particular circumstances, a white dwarf can have enough left in its cupboard when it collapses that there are enough gravitational thermal energies for the collapse to begin about an hour after the outer layers are blown off by violent eruptions of nuclear burning (SN: 2005 December 31 and 2005 January 7). There are no larger collapsed objects with more leftover energy, so the resulting explosion is twice as bright as the usual supernova.

“We don’t see other diseases with so much attention,” said Dr. Martha Sharan, president of the American Academy of Pediatrics. She’s treated concussions in kids for years, and hopes the recommendations make a difference.
The CDC says if a child suffers a concussion, he or she shouldn’t return to playing sports until getting a clearance from a clinician, who will evaluate the patient three things:
– Immediate symptoms;
– Thought patterns, which may be confused or actions slowed;
– Balance, which may be altered.
The recommendations don’t apply to High School kids because the decision-making on when children return to the field remains the decision of school administrators.

i approved the establishment of the Rail Development Authority (RDA) in March 2018.
The RDA will be a statutory body and a subsidiary of the Indian Railways.
Construction projects on the Railways can account for close to 60% of the total project pipeline of the government.

Coeur de Lion Choir
A concert group performing worldwide and renowned for its imaginative programming. Founded in London in 1979, it has now performed throughout the UK, Europe, and in the USA, Far east,Australia and India, receiving rave reviews for the quality of its music making. Coeur de Lion regularly commissions contemporary Brazilian and Hispanic composers such as Francisco Migno and Pablo Garrido and Indonesian composer, Mansur Bilay (not a Brazilian either). As well as foreign composers, Coeur de Lion has also commissioned and premiered a number of works by English composers such as Francis Jackson, John Schumann, Eric Davidson, Michael Head, Jonathan Harvey, Stephen Warbeck and directors Julian Barnes and Douglas Coombes themselves.

MIDDLETOWN, NJ - The Middletown Township Public Library and the Township of Middletown are pleased to announce the appointment of Kim Rinaldi as Provisional Library Director, beginning on February 1, 2013.
Originally from Holmdel Township, Kim holds a Bachelor of Arts in Management Information Systems from Brooklyn College and an MBA from Indiana Wesleyan University. She recently joined the Middletown Township Public Library after moving to the area from Westerly, Rhode Island, where she served as Executive Director at the Westerly Library.
Kim has experience working in public library systems and non-profit organizations, and brings a broad range of experience, training, and knowledge in management, resource allocation, operations, policy development, and programs with a special emphasis in technology.
A community volunteer herself, Kim is the Vice Chairman of the South Kittatinny School Foundation and trustee of the Highland Hall Presbyterian Church.
She is also a founding member of BrainWright.org, a nonprofit organization that provides by donating learned knowledge.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican lawmakers and the White House.
The White House and conservative U.S. lawmakers went into last-minute discussions pushed by the chairman of a House hearing panel over federal spending policy and President Barack Obama's recently proposed budget for 2014.
But talks in the House are likely to be constrained by conservative lawmakers who criticized a weekend summit with Obama as a "phony" bargaining session and said they would not discuss the budget until Obama moderates his tax and spending policies.
The summit followed several weeks of often-acrimonious negotiations during which House Speaker John Boehner, the top Republican in Congress, said no higher taxes would be agreed upon with Obama.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for on-air shopping plans to spend more than $20 million on prime-time Black Friday spots, three times the amount that it spent during last year’s holiday season, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday.
QVC said the event — which gets its name from the busiest shopping day after the Thanksgiving holiday — will be featured on various cable television networks. In the early hours, there will be video simulcast with the host sprawled out on the storied landing in Rockefeller Center in New York City, the Journal reported.
In the evening, there will be a telecast with a slate of entertainment from a rooftop set on Chicago’s Magnificent Mile, the location for the famous “Santa Land” with the large screaming visage of the big jolly older man every year.

SocialDevCamp Chicago is a weekend long conference and hackathon about the social web. It’s the event for social app developers, mobile developers and designers. SocialDevCamp is a weekend of discussions on social platforms and social architectures, demos of the latest in social app prototypes, and challenges to hackers to solve difficult social questions in software and hardware.
Innovation has always been associated with Chicago. We have a history of innovation in manufacturing, transportation, finance, entertainment, music and Chicago sports are some that come to mind. However, integrate innovation with the emerging socialmes 2.0 and we know have challenges on the horizon that will fundamentally change the face of the city.
These are some of the challenges so far that the city’s residents have proposed on the HACK Chicago website.

Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to appeal to the better angels of America and lift the dreary political atmosphere that accompanied last fall's election. He declared the future is in the bargaining, the deal-making, the compromise.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would be more likely.
Yes we don’t have the greatest reputation when it comes to how women are treated medically, but no country reports high rates like the US did with 26 recent maternal deaths there getting headlines around the world.
What are the reasons that America’s maternity-care system has the worst record on safety, and what can be done to bring it into compliance?
Dr. Pia Salk, author women’s health and medicine, gives us some insight.
She claims the vastness of the United States is a factor in the high infant mortality rates.
The US population represents 4% of the total population on the planet, but many regions are seeing maternal mortality rates at least twice that of the global average, in comparison with the Czech Republic and Belarus.

President Trump’s decision Monday to revive plans to freeze federal employee pay in 2020 and to institute a series of cuts to federal employee retirement programs was met with great consternation from stakeholder groups. Many union officials expressed concern over the White House decision not to continue a policy the president declared a progressive value.
Employees across a broad range of federal agencies spoke about the decisions with dismay, as some wondered how the plan to “put people’s lives on hold” would affect the continued growth of the federal workforce at a time when the country faces serious national security challenges.
“Without a doubt, basic pay is the key factor in retaining and recruiting a qualified, well-qualified workforce. If the president wants top talent in a government that will play with a good team and adhere to policies that keep the nation safe, the effective tools are paying well, taking care of them, and being equitable with those responsible,” said Shipmates Federal Council President Rob Burton.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate planet with more than twice the gravity of Earth last week, researchers are pushing that factor into the mix. Water is one thing – a world with twice the gravity of Earth means twice the pull.
Present-day life owes a lot to the constant gravitational push and pull through its pesky oceans, keeping the planet tilted on its axis and influencing global weather patterns. A world with twice the gravity could get hit with twice the bombardment of water vapour, snow, hail and sand. Even inside the fracture zones and crustal faults, the weight of a twice-Earth-size world would introduce more water and gases than could be contained within a planet of Earth’s size.

Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Ukraine had previously sought to pass on winter prices of about US$200 per 1,000 cubic metres (mcm), to its transit customers, which the Russian side deemed excessive until more helpful prices are agreed upon. As a result, Russia has obliged only pre-payments for 2009 gas supply and export to Europe.
In the event of a failure by Ukrainian officials to reach a new agreement with Gazprom, the European Union has agreed that independent regulators will decide whether to unwittingly allow Gazprom to bypass its own supply terms to Russia.
Russia is expected to compensate Gazprom for a surge relationship — as reported in the Russian press — for electricity supplies to Ukraine and a pull back of gas from Gazprom — a row that recently halted exports to Europe.
European gas prices have already sky-rocketed as a result of supply predictions made by EU officials

Finland faces heightened risks from links between radical Islam and terrorism, according to a fresh report by Finland’s security and intelligence police unit Supo. The unit points to the ongoing Syrian conflict as a source of the increased threat, with potential transferrable skills from the conflict area to the spots where radical Islamic ideology takes root.
Supo wrote in its annual report, published on Friday, that the conditions for terrorism and other serious organized crime in the Nordic country are favourable considering the overall low level of national security risk.
But the report also painted a grimmer picture of domestic security issues, taking into account the higher risk of lone-actor terrorism committed by radicalizing young men in the Nordic region.
"In our opinion the risk could also potentially get very serious in the event of a geopolitical shock causing wide awareness of the conflict between the Isis and the world," Supo head Mikko Lipponen wrote in the foreword of Supo's offical annual report.

TURLOCK , Calif.--At a quiet park in Turlock, California, some ducks were found with their bills zip-tied to their necks, according to KTXL.
Donnelly Park is a place people sometimes take their dogs to for a walk.
But Sharon Fass, park manager, said during a late morning stroll Sunday, she was just about shocked to see one of the resident ducks had the tip of its bill cut off with a grind saw and the duck’s head covered with ammonia-soaked torn rags.
"This is not a way you treat a bird," said Fass. "Anybody with a lot of heart, any of the people that come here to walk their dogs, you know they don't want to see this."

Smartphones can be extensively used by ophthalmologists to visualise the condition of a patient´s cornea before a treatment, according to a new study published in JAMA Ophthalmology journal.
Cornea can become cloudy when the epithalline (normally clear membrane) is affected by treatable medical conditions like infections, ophthalmopathums ( where the cornea can affect the front the of the eye ), injuries and cancers.

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back again and again, is passion.
Consider the way a famous Chicago chef known as Chef Tony (he knows this stuff, so let's call him that) treated fresh blue crabs in the properly sized copper boilers meant for twenty lbs. of live-in crab. His wasn't a casual treatment but a reverent one.
His passion made the crabs sing, scream, and spill their fluids. Both the crabs and the proud owner smiled with satisfaction as the noise finally quietened with the crabs adequately cleaned and ready for processing.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that had been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered a series of statewide conservation measures a year ago to combat drought, including a ban on watering lawns.
The state also ordered local water agencies to take steps to reduce saltwater intrusion into drinking water wells.
The order will take effect in 30 days. Gov. Brown declared a drought emergency in November.
The U.S. Drought Monitor reported the water situation was improving in a number of drought areas, but noted a pair of snow surveys across the Sierra Nevada showed more snow coverage. The snowfall was measured at a below-average 24.5%, but a handful of above-average snowfalls were reported in the High Sierra near the summit of Forlanini Ridge and Pinchot Pass, among other spots.

Content protection features in Windows Vista are preventing customers from playing high-quality video and audio and harming system performance, even as Microsoft neglects security programs that could protect users, computer researcher Peter Gutmann argued at the USENIX security conference.
The Digital Rights Management (DRM) features in the upcoming Windows Vista operating system are making audio and video files useless, even as the same protection programs have suffered security holes, Gutmann argued in a paper he presented during the conference last week.
"This is not just a theoretic problem, either," the security expert wrote in the paper. "These attacks are happening already (and have done so for the past 24 months), and the gulf between reality and hype is becoming wider with every passing day." The DRM technology has problems because it allows only a "single vendor's specific type of user experience" and comprises a "poorly programmed, security-free system at the OS level", he argued.

HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound effect on Native America.
For more than a decade the Montana Department of Justice has tracked the number of deaths based upon race of the victim – it estimates 100 missing or murdered Native Americans in Montana in the last decade, including more than 150 people still in limbo.
Wednesday committee members took up four bills including several bills that would require law enforcement agencies to report the number of unidentified Native or White people who are deceased.

Mismanagement and secrecy have stalled the war on terrorism—and at home its effects reverberate against civil rights.
If September 11 was this generation's Pearl Harbor, the Bush Administration's war on terrorism will soon become a 9/11, a remembered horror with the power to define our time.
The White House has already made the attack our nation's rallying cry. But the administration hasn't shown much concern for freedom or human rights at home. As cases came fast and furious out of New York, the administration vainly complained about "terrorizing innocent citizens" , even while the FBI arrested hundreds of Americans and Muslims on claims of suspected ties to terrorist groups.
President Bush went so far as to sign a sweeping law making tens of thousands of more arrests possible without a warrant. Meanwhile victims are still fighting for the right to assail officials who missed chances to stop the attacks. Others have the right to sue for lost property.

FMCG major Hindustan Unilever (HUL) on Thursday reported a 9 per cent increase in its net profit to Rs 1,444 crore for the December 2018 quarter on account of a reduction in 'net finance costs' and other 'non-operating costs'. Its revenue from operations for the October-December quarter of the financial year (Q3 FY 2020) rose 10.91 per cent to Rs 9,302 crore, according to a filing to the BSE. HUL President (Home Care) Sunil D'Silva said, "HUL registered growth in its Consumer Goods & Services business, beating the inflationary consumer environment."
Net profit during the previous quarter stood at Rs 1,280 crore while it rose 10.83 per cent sequentially to Rs 1,405 crore during the September 2018 quarter.
HUL also reported a net profit of Rs 1,310 crore in the December quarter of the last financial year.

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Coming functions will include location-based services and music distribution - services where global positioning system (GPS) signals allow data to be transmitted directly to a mobile phone and can also allow a player to pick up a song instantly from a place where one friend suggests another is listening.
Opportunities dangled by GPS technology are endless in a mobile world: the Web, music players on the go, virtual communities.
With carriers preparing to introduce the technology into a paying consumer market during the next few years, you could conceivably just hop in your car, call your friend and get a real-time bead on which direction you are heading.

In the run-up to December’s global climate change talks in Cancun, cheers were raised when nations signed an agreement promising major new investments in sustainable forest management.
Yet there are concerns about the authenticity of the agreement in the lead-up to the talks, and the forest industry remains worried that the work of millions of people and billions of trees may not be taken seriously.
The concerns come after delegates representing the 190 countries involved in the UN Framework on Climate Change — or UNFCCC — negotiations signed a deal on negotiated provisions on Reducing Emissions From Deforestation and Forest Degradation — commonly referred to as REDD — at a meeting outside Oslo in August.
There remain concerns about who signed which set of documents, who owns the templates for the reports intended to show the results of the forest projects, and who will review the progress of the projects.

To help solve this problem, Andrew Foote and Emily Woods started Sanivation— No. 55 on the BI 100: The Creators — a sanitation startup that installs in-home toilets that compact human waste into a dry, powder form that can be used to grow potatoes. From a design standpoint, the toilet is gender neutral to appeal to all segments of the population.
On the rare occasions when a toilet breaks, weak men in the neighboring cities will sometimes attempt to fix the toilets themselves. In one particular instance, a broke toilet was fixed by a nine-year old who had to spend a year saving up to buy a soda after the Gloria Jeans collapsed in the last decade. That quick check-up was worth every penny.
Two weeks after he made the trip and got his proper diagnosis (free!) Foote received the medical bill from China. It was 100,000 RMB ($16,700).

MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market by giving the country a bigger cut.
Orders normally go to pre-owned plants which sever domestic supply chains and give technology firms easier control over the rapid improvement of software, something the minister sees as a security threat.
“We have had meetings with Foxconn regarding the possibility of setting up a plant in India but the decision is still pending because discussions are going on with a few other companies,” one official told Reuters, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Foxconn did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment outside of business hours. An official who confirmed the meeting could not immediately be reached for comment after business hours.
Foxconn is the unit of Taiwan’s Hon Hai Precision Industry Co that assembles iPhones and other products for Apple in China.

Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in 1878.
As one of the busiest large account meteorologists in Concord points out, our rainfall is reliably weighed at the Manchester airport.
Head south three or four miles and you get the Concord airport with its rain gauges. That's three major factors affecting how much rain falls here: the weather pattern, the air and the ground.
As the National Weather Service summarizes, "Although the mean sea level air temperature here climbs above 70 (degree fehrenheit) on a year-round basis (as seen above), the higher elevation increases the likelihood that air masses generally reach the region before the air has had enough time to meld with the greater warming. (Newser) – For less than two weeks, Shelby Carter got to be what she wanted most to be—a mother. Now her friends and family in Wyoming, Ill., are honoring the sacrifice she made to save her credit card and a complete stranger's life. Carter had just returned home with her newborn baby from the hospital when she went to withdraw cash from an ATM. Although she was in a hurry, she noticed the late Charles Kucera, 70, apparently frantically paging the police. The commuters "began trying to calm Kucera down," the Chicago Tribune reports, "some were calling the cops." Carter told the dispatcher to have police send an ambulance because Kucera already had a history of mental illness.
While Carter was making that call, relatives on the other end tied a tourniquet around Kucera's arm, trying to stop the bleeding from a self-inflicted gunshot to the wrist. What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of poetry and accuse it of being an opportunity for illusion and self-aggrandizement. We can then all congratulate ourselves on not being illusionists and self-aggrandizers. I, however, refuse the cynical answer: it destroys me too. What can poetry do? It can make a difference: inverted Commas’s book La Salle des martyrs is a valuable testimony which attests to the daily struggle with that which is done to both human beings and the Earth. It is a history of the quotidian violence that constitutes the sum of collective memory whether this memory happens to be that of the global current milieu or that of a particular historical moment, such as prior to World War II. As a friend, poet, and translator of the cabaret innovator Jaques Prévert once told me in response to a similar question, the only peace treaty worth signing is poetry.

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not cause cancer, a European Union food safety agency said on Thursday.
The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) pesticide unit said that the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) had performed a sufficiently robust literature review to classify the worldwide use of the chemical as constituting a “carcinogenic hazard for humans”.
But the committee found the classification was not supported by the most recent mechanisms-of-action literature on the chemical, nor was the case made that the chemical was present long enough in the body of humans and mammals to cause its effects, the EFSA said.

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, who is the third longest tenured news organization executive in the state, announced his plan to retire Tuesday.
Under Berthiaume’s leadership, the Post-Crescent earned two Pulitzer Prizes, numerous Green Eye Shade awards, multiple NDNEA weekly awards and the Medium Merit Wisconsin Newspaper Association top newspaper award.
The newspaper, based in Appleton, is owned by Gannett Co., Inc.
Under the leadership of Gannett Co. Inc., (GCI) the Post Crescent has been struggling just as all other GCI held newspapers are experiencing. It’s worth monitoring for future developments.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As the first Christian Platonic philosopher, he also had a decisive influence on later Christian theology.
After the death of his famous mentor Syrianus (405 C.E.) The theology of the Constantinopolitan church had already broken with the theological father, Athanasius, because the latter did not differentiate in the conflict with the Arians between the Trinity of Christianity and the concept of the logos expressing the substance of the world in Platonism (the tome of 367).

Centralizing the procurement process, diversifying supplier portfolios and assessing the capabilities of each manufacturing partner will allow enterprises to mitigate the impact of or eliminate product recalls.
In 1986, one of the world’s largest food companies discovered a problem with one of their condensed milk products. The defective can was marked with the date code “041086” -- meaning it expired on Oct. 4, 1986. Upon receiving complaints, the company voluntarily withdrew the product from the retail market. It then used this withdrawn lot for a subsequent recall for undeclared sulfites, which the company discovered in the review of the 041086 lot’s records.
While neither the product recall nor the subsequent recall was directly attributable to the company, it did result in two reprimands, the payment of a civil penalty and a formal warning letter from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for failures in product quality practices.

Renting an apartment with bad credit may not be easy. Many large apartment complexes owned by corporations now require credit checks and will refuse applicants who do not meet their standards. Even if you have the income to pay for the apartment, if the owners of these property management companies don’t receive enough renters with a credit score that meets their standards, they may deny you an apartment if you have a bad credit history. (CN) – A federal appeals court in New Orleans upheld Mississippi’s three-drug method of lethal injection on the ground that the inmates challenging it had filed their complaint too late.
Michael Walker and Patrick Swain are petitioners in the case, brought on behalf of a class of Mississippi inmates who challenged the three-drug plan that Mississippi had come up with about a decade ago after decades of botched executions.
Those original lethal injection procedures involved either just one drug or a combination of several, including the now-discredited barbiturates sodium pentobarbitol and phenergan, also known as promethazine.
Walker and Swain filed their complaint on June 20, 2017, a little more than a year after Mississippi adopted new procedures on Oct. 5, 2016.
The two challenged Mississippi’s choice of three drugs – midazolam, vecuronium bromide and potassium chloride – saying it presented a risk of cruel and unusual punishment.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. People don’t want the burden of hunting for information in a lot of misaddressed and poorly addressed envelopes.
Before you start the process of addressing the envelope and putting it in the mail, you must decide who you are sending the letter to. If it is a letter that needs to go to a group or department within a corporation, you must conduct some research so that you know how the company is configured and how to address the letter to the appropriate receiver.
If you are writing to a small organization, local businessmen or professionals, you can simply gather the name, company title and address for your recipient. If you are uncertain of the company’s layout or don’t have the means or the time to check it out, you can take a more general approach by using the recipient’s full name.
One legal representative described the brainstorming process he uses to determine the appropriate intended recipient for a letter

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genetics can determine how men age. As a man loses his natural mane, it appears on the forehead, the hairline recedes, eventually resulting in a one-sided patch of bare skin.
Various drugs are available across the world for the treatment of hereditary male pattern baldness. There’s a bolder than ever group of solutions (termed Finasteride) whose proactive nature will halt or even reverse the early signs of baldness.
All publicly listed Finasteride products are available in Australia (and are legal), but due the risk of genetic gender confusion, some privately owned online pharmacies also have access.
The medication is prescribed by doctors with authority to issue a medical certificate. Choosing the right med is important (you’re paying for a prescription, after all). There are three products to choose from – all are effective:
Finasteride / Prope

The big "oops."
And the ones that followed.
Behind the facade of the Acadiana Cultural Center — where for the next month the final tally in the presidential election between Barack Obama and John McCain will be crunched — officials tripped over their votes Tuesday night. People found them. People helped uncover ones lost.

Gov. Greg Abbott refused to pick sides Wednesday in a growing squabble over how best to cut state taxes, and moved away from an earlier promise to “insist” that Texas lawmakers cut property taxes, the single largest source of the taxes Texans pay.
A high-stakes throwdown with potential Republicans across the state who favor income tax cuts over cutting property taxes probably isn't what Abbott had in mind a couple of weeks ago when he spoke from the State Capitol steps. He pushed an idea for the Legislature — which just ended one meeting period — to pass more bills cutting property taxes and declared that lawmakers needed to do so voluntarily because Texans are already taxed enough.
But some conservative lawmakers opposed greater cuts, saying some of the ideas Abbott had offered, especially a border adjustment exemption, would ultimately cause more taxes if the state didn't have the money. When Abbott and lawmakers don't meet expectations, conservatives often embrace the idea that taxpayers don't get the bang for their buck, either.

A memorial service is planned for Fort Bragg City Councilman Jere Melo at 2 p.m. Sept. 10 at the Timberwolf Stadium on Chestnut Street in Fort Bragg.
He died Aug. 24 from complications of a diabetic illness, according to his Facebook page.
Melo moved to the area in 2001 after retiring from the Marines following 22 years of active service. He deployed as part of the Marine Aerial Mine Neutralization Service team with NATO during the Gulf War.
A veteran of the Panama military intervention and the Battle of Mogadishu (Blackhawk Down), he was deployed twice more in Afghanistan. He earned a bachelor’s degree from Ashford University in 2000 and a certificate from the Army’s military armorers school in 2003.

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, leading to increasingly acidic ocean conditions. This condition is expected to worsen in the coming decades as the result of continued CO2 emissions.
A new University of Delaware study offers support for the preservation of workhorse species as a way to mitigate these changes, recommending a greater emphasis on managing shellfish restorations in particular.
Sharp’s team studied restoration efforts worldwide aimed at aiding economically important bivalves species, the family of mollusks that includes oysters and clams.
In a study published in the journal Marine Biology, the team summarized the restoration literature into the territory of closed oyster reefs and projected the future trajectory of restoration success rates based on available knowledge about how estuarine ecosystems respond to more acidic conditions.

Since going off Aleve, I have had more skipped heart beats, so I decided to call my cardiologist for help with my caffeine consumption.
I have been so culpable with coffee intake this past week. Caffeine is a stimulant and does keep you alert. I can feel my stomach bouncing around in my rib cage after a couple cups. Negatively affects PVCs (PaThØmVulcAr production).
So, let’s talk about how coffee can affect your heart.
Stimulant (caffeine): Caffeine is a stimulant in the form of a diuretic. Diuresis can augment heart workload. Metabolic rate: If heart	rate remains elevated, coffee can increase your risk of	atrial fibrillation (seed).
Blood pressure: Both systolic and diastolic may increase.

PROFESSOR Peter Higgs of Edinburgh University may now stand as a scientific legend alongside the likes of Newton, Oppenheimer and Einstein.
But the Noble laureate-in-waiting is far from the arid figure many expect him to be.
He's seventy-six so his hair has gone a little grey, and he sports a grey beard, but there's a bounce in his step that reflects the youth of his brain.
His spare but comfortable farmhouse study on the outskirts of Edinburgh is the home of lost bodies crammed with writing.
Not Ukrainian poetry though.
His Vietnamese students file past yesterday to have their math exam corrected with a word or two of encouragement: "You can do it", "Hang in there", "Not bad, but can you improve? Yes you can", "Best wishes", "Look after yourself".
Higgs is a fond grandfather with a wife whom he met when she was a student at the same University.
She has made his job easier by helping him with his paperwork and research over the years.

Pulitzer Prize-winning author Philip Roth resorts to public channels to get a Wikipedia entry changed...and succeeds.
After writing an open (and, of course, extremely eloquent) letter that was published in the New York Times [link], the entry was changed by a reverence towards the author and the powerful structures of the network.
The letter also was published on Philip Roth's website.
I jokingly suggested "flamewar" for the power dynamic, and I'm sure you'll agree Wikipedia nickname is conducing to a more even playing field.
Collective intelligence, authorship, co-creation, participatory media and the democratization of cultural production are just a few driving conditions to the Wikipedia media system. For more detail, see David White's paper "Life after Wikipedia (for Academic Art Professionals)"
But the vexing project of figuring out who owns the cultural product seems not to have so much to do with technology yet, nor with a utopian collective intelligence, but with a matrix of legal structures that haven't caught up yet with the powerful and ubiquity of the network itself.

London: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would not be derailed from leaving the EU without a deal in March to avert a "disastrous" no-deal outcome, amid hopes a spare parliamentary vote could be secured later this week for the plan.
Conservative lawmaker Jacob Rees-Mogg was one of a group of Brexit hardliners who met May on Saturday night to press for a no-deal Brexit at the end of March.
"Amid all the noise, we are getting on with the job ... we will get this done," May wrote in the Sunday Telegraph.
"I am going to continue doing my job - getting the best possible deal (the plan) we can get and helping the country to get ready for the change in the wind of 29 March next year when we leave the EU," she said.

The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
The big vote by the National Executive Board is taking place the day after nearly 700,000 Scouts participate in the organization’s major jamboree near Washington - its first at the sprawling Summit Bechtel Reserve.
It comes nine months after the board voted to end the blanket ban following careful study after years of pressure.
The board also is deliberating whether to allow gay youths in a long-stated goal of the Scouts consistent with their purpose to look out for their well-being.
If the resolution confronting the so-called ‘two-deep’ rule is approved as is expected by a subcommittee, that could clear the way for an eventual change for Scouting units sponsored by churches that require Scouts to adhere to church teaching. Under the resolution, such units could choose to continue the ban.

Somehow, somewhere, deep down, in the middle of the solar plexus, but maybe deeper, we all knew the famous, and then infamous, "25 Things List" that dominated Facebook a few months back would yield a pit of problems for those who made fools of themselves for all the world to see. The assault on our privacy legislation in so many countries though, probably rates as the nastiest demerit of all.
After all, these are things we never intended that one stranger might know about us, even if that stranger drags the fruits of their former lives into the light of publicity to behave badly and agressively towards a like-minded person, one anonymous among millions of others. Tributes have been paid to young Teesside mum Laura Hodgson who has lost her fight for life.
Laura, from Billingham , was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer last year.
The mum of a one-year-old had previously battled the disease on several occasions before, leaving her on a cocktail of medications, including the treatment Herceptin.
Laura never regained the strength to see her young son Finley after being rushed to hospital with a cerebral haemorrhage last month and died peacefully on Friday morning.
Her family spoke of her bravery as she fought the illness a second time.
An inquest into Laura's cause of death is to be opened and adjourned on December 7.
Her brother Paul Thompson wrote a heartbreaking poem in memory of Laura called 'Once I Held A Lighter' posted on his Facebook page along with a touching tribute.

Since the 1980s, there’s been a national conversation about how to prevent school shootings. Research into the people who commit mass shootings has found three typical profiles: the lone gunman, a group of peers, or a cult.

The total VR market will generate $5.1 billion this year, new report claims.
2016 is poised to be the year that virtual reality really gets going, as Oculus Rift, PlayStation VR and HTC Vive all vie for your disposable income. The VR wave, though, is more than just three headsets. On the higher end, PC graphics cards are available with onboard virtual reality technology, while all the major smartphone makers are rushing to capitalize on the epic surge in virtual reality. A man from Alsip has been charged with the fatal shooting of a 33-year-old man in the South Chicago neighborhood, police said.
Brandon Ewing, 24, of the 3700 block of South Alsdorf Avenue, was charged with first-degree murder in the Oct. 18 slaying of Herbert Phillips, according a news release issued Monday afternoon.
Ewing was arrested Oct. 19 and was scheduled to appear in Cook County Circuit Court on Tuesday.
An autopsy performed on Phillips on Oct. 18, according to the Cook County Medical Examiner’s office, ruled the Carole Street man’s death a homicide. Phillips was shot several times.
Phillips was found with multiple gunshot wounds on the floor of a second-floor bedroom.
Ewing is also wanted for the Oct. 16 shooting of a 30-year-old man who was found with gunshot wounds to the left side of his abdomen in the 900 block of West 110th Street.

When and where does the Torchlight Procession take place?
In recent years the Torchlight Procession has been the Saturday before New Year's Eve (28 December 2019) in the city centre. Dietrich Bonhoeffer has always been one of my great heroes of the faith. Such appreciation, of course, hardly makes me distinct. Bonhoeffer, the German pastor-theologian who opposed the Nazis and was executed in 1945 as a co-conspirator in the assassination of Adolf Hitler, is one of Christianity's shining lights, and the one to which so many look for nuanced guidance about Christian resistance to tyranny and other harmful evils.
As a (Jewish) woman who experienced anti-Semitic persecution at the hands of the Nazi regime, the Holocaust spoke with a particular power to Bonhoeffer and drove much of his theological work. As the holocaust approached, he concerned himself more critically with the effects of history, embracing what we call life as the one place God can be perceived. (Bonhoeffer did not yet know that the World War II era would inaugurate history’s cruelest engagement with that age-old theological conundrum.) The Michigan Chapter of the Antique and Classic Boat Society had nearly 200 boats lined up in the Black River between Seventh and 10th streets. The previous record for an ACBS International Boat Show was 170 boats.

The lower channel between Bay Harbor and Gills Roads became a sea of antique and classic boats.
As the morning progressed, the Double Lot Bay filled with these beautiful boats.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Farouk was arrested after publishing a book titled "Silence the Byte" in March, blogger and human rights activist Abdullah Elshamy said.
Elshamy, who was jailed for more than 200 days last year for allegedly staging anti-government protests, could not immediately explain the arrest. But he said his friend Farouk normally writes about diverse topics such as music and sports.
Two security sources did not immediately explain the arrest. Lawyer Mohamed Abdel Mahmoud confirmed Farouk's arrest, saying he had been released later on Sunday.
Saidiq Abul Nashnossim, Farouk's wife, said the arrest stemmed from security services mounting a crackdown after Islamist radicals killed 26 soldiers in the country's Sinai Peninsula on Saturday.

Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, Calif.-based firm’s workforce, currently about 74 employees, to 47.
The top two executives, Chief Executive Angela Hwang and Chief Business Officer Yeming Luo, resigned.
“With the tremendous costs of sponsoring clinical trials and the need to control cash outflows, one option was to restructure the company,” Hwang wrote in an email.
Aduro filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on July 14 in the Federal District Court for the District of Delaware.
Although the company had disclosed the restructuring, it did not take steps to preserve the value of any potential licensing outcomes or related commercial opportunities.

The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car approval process is one of the Commission's so-called "college" powers that allow the vice-presidents of the executive, plus the transport commissioner, to object to the decision of the college chief.
This accessory power appears to have been seldom used in the past, according to public documents seen by the EUobserver.
But president Jose Manuel Barroso's new college has given it the firm hand that the Commission always intended to apply it in pursuit of its zero-emission car goals, the documents reveal.
The accessory power was one of the dim sub-themes of a debating event in Tallinn, Estonia, that the Commission held last Thursday (26 May).

The sales volume of MOIL is predominately into the domestic market and hence its revenue and profitability are directly related to the average realisation. The final group of Irish peacekeepers to serve in Chad arrived back in Dublin this afternoon.

The 180 members of the peacekeeping force were sworn in along with 500 Gambia and Sri Lankan troops at a ceremony at the European Union headquarters in Brussels yesterday.

One week after a dog spooked by fireworks was hit by a SkyTrain, resident Bruce Mitchell is asking the City of Vancouver to revisit its fireworks bylaws.
On Oct. 29 2017, a man was walking his three dogs near the Commercial-Broadway SkyTrain station after a fireworks display.
He stopped at a pedestrian crossing at the Fraser Street and Nanaimo Street intersection so that one dog would not run into the intersection. Meanwhile, the other dog, a vizsla named Shadow, ran through the intersection and was hit by the train.
The accident left the rescue dog with non-life threatening injuries, but clearly stressed the man, Bradford Balasin, and the train operator, Brian Kretschmer.
Balasin, a south Burnaby BC resident, feared that something like this would happen one day and he hopes this accident and all the media attention that came with it will force the City of Vancouver and the transit hub owners (TransLink) – to ban the sale and use of fireworks in the Vancouver area.

The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his prepared opening statement, Powell said GDP growth has rebounded in the second quarter and showed signs of firming in the third, which followed a slowdown over the winter quarter.
“I would say … the economy remains strong,” the Fed boss said ahead of questions from members of the House financial services committee.
As previously announced by the central bank, the committee is due to increase rates during its September meeting — a decision that is widely expected and consensus sees all seven committees voting for a 0.25 percent rise in the Fed funds rate.
Strengthening the economy, in the medium term the Fed has suggested it will keep increasing rates by a quarter-point four more times this year.
This ongoing tightening of monetary policy is expected to continue for the next three years or so — a series of gradual, small rises based on what the Fed calls a sound US economy — with the central bank room to act if necessary

'Black Panther''s box office dominance continues as the Marvel blockbuster passed 'Titanic' to become the third highest-grossing film of all time.
Black Panther‘s box office dominance continues to soar with the latest batch of release update figures, which arrive as the superhero movie eclipsed Titanic to become the third highest-grossing film of all time.
The Walt Disney Company said Saturday that the 15th Marvel movie has become the eight domestic blockbuster with a worldwide cume of more than $1.3 billion in ticket sales.
All three figures are lifetime records, surpassing Star Wars: The Force Awakens ($2 billion) and Titanic ($2.1 billion).
Black Panther‘s previous ticket sales hail primarily from international markets, with the movie expecting to do steady business into the summer.
At the time of its international release, Black Panther was on track to be the third film to pass the $1 billion mark worldwide after the second Avengers movie ($1.4 billion) and Star Wars: The Last Jedi ($1.3 billion).

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden in December 1898.
It was discovered a few months ago on a beach on Kampen in the Netherlands - more than 5,000km (3,100 miles) from the North Sea.
The letter inside was never picked up - and the call ends with the words "Here's wishing all your family a Merry Christmas and a happy New Year".
It took more than a century for the bottle to wash up on normal Dutch shores, after heading towards Britain.
The message is (from the letter):
Dear Sir - I have the Honor to inform you that the crossing on board the above Navigable will take place from Christmas Eve until New Year (Eve) 26 (to Christmas Eve!)

“God’s Plan” was named the Best Rap Song.
Drake’s smash hit “God’s Plan” just received the Grammy Award for Best Rap Song.
The big news story may not, however, be the fact that the song won the award (because it already was one of the biggest songs of the week). More impressive is the fact that Drake is tied with Eminem for the most wins in the category.
With nine wins now in these particular genre categories, Drake earned this coveted title in relative record time. (The 30-year-old is only the show’s 13th-ever double winner in the category).
Having just recently tried his hand at acting, the Canadian native is also just one win shy of Billy Joel‘s all-time record of more Oscar, Golden Globe, and Grammy wins among all individuals.

The U.S. military likely has more experience providing humanitarian aid with standard army procedures, and nearly all were developed after government declarations of a national emergency. The Narromine Garden Club have gifted their annual donation to local organisation the Narromine Volunteer Rescue Association (VRA).

"It does make a big difference to what we can do with the things that are unbudgeted, particularly more people are travelling so we get a lot of people having to travel to Sydney to the Children's hospital, so the amount might seem like nothing but it can make a difference," Mrs Brown said.

Vicki Denton, who on vacation to Orlando from Ohio, perused items in the gift shop at Hollywood Studios when the alleged incident occurred in 2016.
A woman who contends she was injured after being struck with a Hard Rock Cafe baseball cap in Disney World's Hollywood Studios is seeking more than $15,000 in damages from the restaurant that bills itself as "As seen in the Muppets' movie."
The incident occurred nearly two years ago, when Vicki Denton's boyfriend paid for their large party -- including their three children -- to see the MuppetVision show and shop in the area. During the visit, Denton was allegedly approached by a cast member, who she believes wanted a tip.
"I went into the gift shop and I was looking; I was looking for my glasses. While I was looking for my glasses, one of the cast members -- a young man – approached me and said, 'Can I help you with your glasses?' " she said.
"I said, 'Yes.' He took my glasses and threw something into the box," she said.

Two officers of a company that operates three Manhattan hotels were indicted yesterday in a scheme to help homeless people fraudulently obtain welfare checks and split the money with the hotels.
District Attorney Robert S. Johnson said the scheme allowed the hotels to defraud the welfare system, collect overpayment of bills and unfairly obtain more property tax abatements under the Government Shutdown Aid Program.
The indictments are the first and largest against New York hotels under the penthouse abatement law, which provides a tax break and tax reimbursement to hotels that offer the most affordable lodgings in the city, with the most at risk of shutting down.
Under the Penthouse Hotels Program for the last three years to give the owners the abatement, the companies had to reserve more than one-third of the rooms for people who make less than $15,000 a year and people switching from a homeless shelter or group homes.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies own their own servers, many smaller providers only have a limited number of servers to rent server space to clients. To expand their business, these small providers may offer advertised services such as a white-label reseller program.
A white-label reseller program is one that starts with a small hosting company buying a large quantity of servers from a larger company, along with other infrastructure, according to the eNom website. The small hosting company has the customized system installed on-site, and then configures the system to boot up a Linux or Microsoft system. They then allow clients to use the system, with the host providing full support to clients. This allows smaller providers to offer services that are the same as larger providers offer, but with the same costs for the client.
A small provider may have a single server that runs about 50 people's websites, according to the Inc. website. That's a relatively modest

Consumers purchasing IBM PCs will soon get their computers pre-configured for free Internet access from Juno Online Services.
The companies today announced a multiyear distribution agreement, with IBM bundling Juno connection software with new computers at no extra charge to consumers.
Juno President David Mandelstam today said that the deal with IBM is the first of many agreements the five-year-old company is seeking and expects to close soon with several other major computer manufacturers.
This will be a leading play in the continued evolution of the Internet infrastructure from dial-in, dial-up to pre-distribution and provisioning of complete IP services.
Under the agreement, IBM clients registering for the one-year Juno Plan, which provides free Internet connectivity, can get their modems automatically configured for connection to the Juno service upon activation, the companies said.
IBM will also increase computer purchases of Juno PCs and laptops during all corporate and consumer product launches in the future, according to the companies.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Mortality Rate – the number of baby deaths during the first 28 days after birth – was 4.2 babies per 1000 live births in 2013. This represents a more than 30 percent improvement since 1990, but the improvement has slowed in the last three years.
A small improvement is not enough to encourage communities that adopt the March of Dimes – led Perinatal Collaboratives method, which helps communities make a rapid, significant improvement in improving birth outcomes by implementing evidence-based best practices in communities.

The Public Service Commission on Wednesday approved a pilot program intended to create up to 350 megawatts of long-term renewable power within the next three years, a move that state officials and environmentalists say could help expedite the integration of renewable energy across 15 western states.
The program, called the Western Power Imbalance Service, is a competitive auction plan that allows transmission owners to have their projects paid for by the participation of all the states — a concept that was designed as a compromise between conservation advocates and the Western energy grid operator.
“Carrying forward with the idea that the customers in other states get to see the value of the resource, also shares collections across the other states, compared to separate cost-of-service recovery when you’re only charging one state,” said Larry Beehler, executive director of the Association of California Utilities.

Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy from the heat generated in the planet’s interior. Yet, tantalizing energy from a third source, tidal energy, eludes estimates.
A new study published April 20 in the journal Science adds another piece to the puzzle as to how Earth stays energized. Measuring subtle changes in Earth’s rotation (modulation), scientists calculated the magnitude of tidal energy needed to explain the behavior. This means that tidal energy is only needed to explain a fraction of fluctuations seen in Earth’s rotation. The researchers concluded that tidal energy moves the needle impacting the final rate of the rotation, but tidal energy alone cannot explain the rotation altogether.
“To keep a constant orbit, the background rotation rate estimates need to be supplemented by a smaller but finite tidal energy source,” Akila De Silva, the lead author told Universe Today. “This study shows the magnitude of a plausible tidal

BOSTON – A disgraced former state chemist may have tainted more prosecutions than officials had first estimated, an independent reviewer of narcotics cases said Tuesday.
More than 400 convictions and jail sentences have so far been reviewed or vacated if blood samples hadn't been checked for evidence of tampering, the Administrative Office of the Division of Professional Licensure (DPL) said.
The flaw gives defendants the right to get a new trial if they want one.
Hundreds more cases remain under review in Suffolk County, said an independent review of Suffolk County prosecutions ordered by the district attorney following the scandal, made public on Tuesday.
Though few people who had been convicted through the unchecked blood samples have applied for new trials, the discovery of the tainted samples had already prompted the Attorney General's Office to vacate drug charges against a Greenwich, Conn., narcotics dealer, officials said.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the University of Coimbra, in Coimbra, Portugal, recruited 25 yoga practitioners and compared them with 25 individuals who did no yoga or other aerobic exercise during the study. Both groups were put on three separate occasions through a battery of psychological evaluations, including a test which required participants to transition rapidly from one task to the next.
Individuals who practiced yoga showed marked improvement in their ability to switch between tasks much quicker than those who were assigned non-yoga exercises.
Wim Audenaarde, a medical practitioner and researcher at Coimbra, is a long-time yoga practitioner and studied the potential correlations between the practice and brain function in his study.

Investor action group Market Forces took a closer look at the emissions reductions solutions being touted by some of Australia’s worst emitting corporations in their 2016 annual reports and found plans that suggest no tangible emission reductions are possible for any of the corporations until 2050.

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data series comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregular in time and location, and notable only for their rarity. Explore the ice, climate, and geophysical data and construct your own historical puzzles. The Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive energizes science, education, and human understanding of the high north through a comprehensive data listing of Arctic sea ice maps, science, and societal use of the sea ice records. The ACSYS vision is to advance knowledge and genomic design regarding how environmental change, economic development, and nature/society relationships operate in and with the polar regions. This simple data access and distribution project aims to enhance transdisciplinarity related to polar studies for researchers

Thomas Jefferson wrote about Revere in his 1821 autobiography, the only full account of this event he had: "On the first day of April, 1775, the election of officers [for the Massachusetts Bay colony] was closed, and the Congress met the same day, and continued to the fifth, when the spirited and intelligent Mr. Revere was chosen Major of the company that was afterwards called Minutemen."
After the battles on Lexington and Concord, Revere spurred a horse at midnight through the moonlight towards Boston. He carried a summons from his local commander in Waitesborough (now Watertown), ordering Minutemen to arms and for the countryside to gather at the meeting-house in the morning. Which Irish names are making a comeback?
For the fifth year in a row, Emily was the most popular female baby name in Ireland in 2015. Emily finished the year ahead of Emma, Ava, Sofia and Aoife in the baby name rankings compiled by the Central Statistics Office.
On the male side of the ledger, Jack beat Ethan, David and James to the top spot for baby boys with Mohammad (Mum’s the word – no one knows how to pronounce this one), Samuel (Sam? Seumas?) and Ruaidrí (circa 1000) rounding out the top three.
While the total variation in all the Irish names was 50% at the start of the millennium, it had fallen 15% by 2009. Use of traditional Irish personal names plateaued during the middle years of the 20th century.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter Maya.
Karnow's acclaimed work on Vietnam, "In Our Image," was published in 1989 and won the National Book Award. He later returned to the subject to write a four part series that appeared in the Washington Post from August through November 2012.
His other books include biographies of Winston Churchill and Indian leader Mahatma Gandhi, entitled "Churchill," and "Mahatma: Life and Thought."

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify the potential impact of the options they have with a task. The diagram shows the consequences of a decision – the probability of the decisions' outcomes, and the costs and benefits associated with each outcome.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to evaluate the impact of potential business choices on a business’s profitability.
The roots of the tree are the important assumptions made for a task – errors or wrong behaviour at the root are irreversible and can have a major impact on profitability.
The branches of the tree represent possible choices and their impact on profitability – a decision can either increase or decrease profitability.
Like a treasure hunt, decision trees are a great way to understand the impact of a decision on your future.
Decision Trees help you ...
A decision tree helps you to make more logical decisions by making your own assumptions explicit. This is because the decision tree simply records the logic of your decision.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp.
Due to limitations in the technology, though, the clone stamp had to be applied to an image that you had already saved. You couldn’t just paste layers over one another with no cleanup. But now with Photoshop’s latest update, you can do just that.
The update lets you create “sample layer fill” (only compatible with layers, not Smart Objects). Impressively, the tool recognizes patterns from the area that you’re removing rather than just blending where the pixels match. Adobe says the (also AI-driven) auto composite tool can fill up to 82 percent of the area you’re covering in a satisfactory way if you don’t adjust the parameters.
