The Campaign for Liberty, a libertarian advocacy group founded by congressman and presidential candidate Ron Paul (R-TX), is campaigning against three bills on Capitol Hill, asserting that the proposed legislation encroaches on individual privacy.
The group is particularly concerned with Federal Aviation Administration reauthorization (H.R. 658), which it says limits freedom of speech by requiring airlines to collect flight passenger information, internet records and credit cards information.
The Campaign for Liberty also opposes the Stop Online Piracy Act (H. R. 3261), arguing that copyright law already allows IP owners to take legal action against piracy. The group adds that the proposed legislation would allow the government to censor the Internet and strip Internet users of their privacy when it comes to their websites, software and other connected services.

A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot flirtations with younger men. For this research, participants completed an in-depth anonymous questionnaire in which they responded to intimacy inventories designed to gauge their sexual behavior with a potential mate. Participants also responded to “wandering eye” inventories designed to gauge their female mates’ infidelity.
When both the researchers and the participants pooled the data across the two samples, the results exhibited striking differences between grandmothers and those with no kids or grandkids of their own. Across all age brackets, grandmothers were less likely than other women to stray. Her goal? She wishes to break the record at the age of 51.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just one of the many benefits of buying a commercial application. For small and midsized businesses that cannot justify the high ticket price of software, the wonder is why the same kind of commodity access to source code isn't more prevalent.
The reasons include deep disbelief in the age-old fairy tales, a stubborn belief that proprietary applications development is the efficient way to get to the store, and the simple fact that many SMBs don't even have applications-development departments.
Enterprises also get closer relationships with vendors of large applications, relationships that small businesses may not benefit from to the same extent. IBM can lean on the developers of OpenOffice.org to get their customization work done, for example.

University Health Network and Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network are creating a value-based health alliance that will ultimately provide statewide coverage.
A new partnership between doctors and facilities affiliated with University of Tennessee Medical Center and Vanderbilt Health aims to create a network that will span all of the state, providing affordable access to care for Tennesseans of all income brackets.
The alliance announced on Tuesday does not immediately guarantee all eligible residents the chance to enroll in health plans, but an administrator said the group of medical facilities nearing 80,000 patients are aiming for near-universal coverage across the state within the next decade.
The transition to taking a risk-pool based term reimbursement model rather than the traditional fee-for-service model should allow the network to expand reach and address the demand for more quality, affordable care, said Billy Phillips, chief development officer for Nashville-based Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network.
“Medicare is paid on a population-based model, which is a fair payment system for the quality and the cost of care,” Phillips said.

I wasn’t sure what I would see or experience when I arrived. It was a sunny morning, and it all seemed surreal. How could people be living in a tent during the day?
What I found upon arrival was a diverse group of people all living with the full realization of what it means to live in a tent. Groups of men, women, a handful of children. Everyone openly getting together and talking with one another as the community lifted tents. RICHMOND HILL - A Bryan County inmate temporarily released to be treated for a spider bite has returned to the Southeast Probation Detention Center in Claxton to continue serving his 30-day jail sentence.
Police and medical officials say the prisoner did not have to be hospitalized after the bite.
State Department of Corrections officials transferred him to Emory University's hospital in Atlanta to be examined after he arrived at the jail facility after complaining of a burning sensation.
The General Counsel's Office of the state Attorney General says the patient had no history of being bitten by a black widow. The spider, found primarily in western Georgia, is one of the world's most poisonous varieties. Intense local redness and swelling after the fang-inflicted bite may indicate poisoning by a black widow.
A Georgia Bureau of Investigation Agent is looking into the inmate's release.

The statue of Robert the Bruce at The Battle of Bannockburn Centre. PIC: Michael Gillen/Falkirk Herald.
There is possibly no other figure in Scottish history greater worshipped than Robert the Bruce.
Pardoned by the Pope immediately after his death, the Bruce occupies a unique standing among the kings, with a reputation for unselfishness and generosity.
His achievements during the Wars of Independence brought him close to divine status. Certainly his eventual independence for Scotland was a god-given gift.

We want you to have a safe ride with the Lyft app, so we take the safety of all riders and bicycles very seriously. We are currently taking steps to support riders including finding alternate transportation and arranging to cover the cost of rides with alternate transportation.
Lyft also announced a new partnership with Swiftmile, a bike-sharing and electric bicycle startup, that lets riders use the app to book bikes in the Bay Area.

On October 30, a major new report on the impact of Marcellus Shale gas development on water resources will be issued. Water Resource Reporting and Water Footprint from Marcellus Shale Development in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, prepared by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) Ames, Iowa Water Science Center, is intended to help guide the development and conservation of water resources in Marcellus Shale gas development. The report provides estimates of the average water consumption by the natural gas industry during the period of 2000-2011, based upon applicable water use permits and production levels. The water-use estimates from this time period are the most complete estimates of actual water use currently available for the full range of the Marcellus Shale gas resource in both West Virginia and Pennsylvania. This report is the first of its kind at this scale.
The report also provides estimates of the total water volume consumed by the top producing values in the Marcellus Shale gas resource. Both reports correct for the fact that natural gas currently produced from this resource is composed primarily of methane (40 to 99 percent of the total) and requires less water than conventional

In your lifetime, you've wished upon many stars.
You've spotted a twinkle in the night sky and hoped for love or fulfillment of a dream. You've wished for good grades, better money, a teddy bear. Maybe you just turned seven and can't get the idea of being a Bratz doll or a magician out of your head. But you probably haven't wished upon a falling star.
They are unpredictable compared to shooting stars flaming across the sky, little streaks of light that sometimes leave burnt-brass scorch marks on your concrete basketball court. Similar to shooting stars, but more prominent. You might have forgotten you wished upon a falling star, just like a shooting star. But a falling star hits you. Hard. You are reminded of your wish.
I didn't wish upon a falling star either. I just sat on the basketball court and watched the stars fall and have nothing. Dead leaves crunching below my feet. Lost hopes, the ghost of a basketball team that was more dribbling drills then team practices.

Sunday will be the 42nd annual Earth Day celebration. Here are six important things to know about the history of the event.
President Jimmy Carter established the first Earth Day, on April 22, 1970. Happy Birthday
Although April is the month for Earth Week, originally the idea for a special celebration first surfaced the fall before, at a 1969 Conference on the Human Environment in Stockholm, Sweden, according to Mother Nature Network.
The first Earth Day in 1970 attracted an estimated 20 million Americans and helped launch a "green" movement.
The most significant outcome of that first Earth Day celebration, according to the Earth Day Network, was the passage of the Clean Air, Clean Water, and Endangered Species Acts mandated by the U.S. Congress.

How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules. This allows them to overcome the inevitable conditions that might time and time again make them fail. However, the lack of an effective ‘rule’ benching a trade can often lead to further losses, large scale account drawdowns and even Bankruptcy of the accounting origins. All these are highly preventable with one rule.
With every possible rule you could have there is one common denominator for all which can never contradict the entry rule (for example the ‘official’ rule in most of the markets is that a trade is only considered to have a ‘loss’ if the trade went from a profit into the red). If you change the ‘rule’ on the market you need to know which element of the 3 to completely modify. There is however one common denominator which can never contradict with any other rule you can have and that is one of the strongest concepts found in Trading.

A bizarre interstellar object called 'Oumuamua continues to perplex astronomers a year after it vanished. Here's why a few scientists still wonder if it was alien.
An illustration of an interstellar object passing close to the sun.Olixar / Shutterstock
An interstellar object called 'Oumuamua has perplexed astronomers since October 19, 2017 -- the night they discovered it.
'Oumuamua was first detected by scientists at the MIT-affiliated Panoramic Survey Telescope And Rapid Response System in Hawaii. It was already on its way out of the solar system, making it the first-ever interstellar object to be discovered in the sky.
The object was observed for only about two weeks as it left our solar system, but during that time scientists identified some strange things about 'Oumuamua.
In the roughly one-year since astronomers announced the object (which means "A Gift from the Clans" in Hawaiian), these enigmas continue.

Looking for calm? Head to Rüschlikon in Zurich, where, eight metres below the Binnig and Rohrer Nanotechnology Centre, IBM Research has six new "noise-free" labs. "The noise floor is about -98 dB, so you lose one decibel using electronically-shaded (or acoustically-shaded) windows and 10 dB with these labs," says Daniel Croitoru, senior project leader.
A major problem with noisy equipment is machining a feature with potential acoustic problems into a part using conventional noise-suppressing methods such as water-filled chambers. The noise is captured inside the fluid and masks the noise from some intended sensor, raising its noise floor.
A traditional way to ignore noise is to delay it in time by moving the sensor beyond the wanted frequency range. A reverse approach is taking current measurements immediately, and filtering out noise later. Measurements directly coupled to delay-free sensors are then more accurate, with their error ranges decreasing in proportion to the length of the delay. Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations can no longer be based on the experience and intuition of the board. "Everyone" can gain access to all data and use it as a basis for decision-making. After all, with the right analytics tools one can even make a large profit with near-zero costs! That is a seductive idea that has persuaded far too many people to take the wrong path.
But the decision-maker must not neglect intuition
The intuition of experienced employees can certainly be wrong, and numerous decisions are also made using human intuition. But officials also made the wrong decisions in the past based on comparison, tabular analysis and so on. Intuition should never be viewed with skepticism and treated with mistrust. That is what the author of "Progress in the Scientific Management Era" wrote more than 70 years ago. According to the author, intuition is nothing more than the ability to compare the relevant information at a glance.

How many gubernatorial elections will Pennsylvania hold this November? A trick question? Yes, sort of – but the question reveals an ongoing war of words over how state law defines a “majority” of votes.
This fight has its roots in March 2008. At the height of the Democratic presidential primaries, the state GOP successfully petitioned the United States Supreme Court to suspend Pennsylvania’s law giving presidential candidates automatic inclusion on the general election ballot if they get the most votes in a primary.
The law, signed into law by Gov. Ed Rendell in 2005, was intended to make the process easier and faster, saving millions of dollars in the process, but the suit argued otherwise. Last March, the U.S. Supreme Court agreed with the GOP, vacating an earlier ruling by Judge Paul Diamond in Federal District Court in Philadelphia.

The move comes two days after Dawn Sturgess died from picking up a counterfeit version of the World War Two nerve agent left in a handle of a discarded flask in Wiltshire.
Ms Sturgess and her partner Charlie Rowley fell ill after handling an old, handle-shaped perfume bottle poisoned in the area of Salisbury.
The rare toxin had the effect of weakening the nervous system, numbing, paralysing and giving victims' skin a blue tint.
British authorities, such as the Health and Safety Executive, will issue warning leaflets detailing a protocol that parents can use to keep their children safe.
If a foreign object looks suspicious, a parent should either drop it straight down into a bucket of very hot water, or will stick it on a rare magnet powerful enough to be able to draw a mobile phone towards it.
The protocol comes after a phase one clean-up of areas affected by the poisonings.

Worshippers were infuriated. The problem, religious experts explain, is that Mr Tusk appears to mistake Damascus for a location of punishment.

A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had departed Seattle around noon Pacific time and was due to arrive in Los Angeles at 6 p.m. Pacific time.
Instead, the crew was required to return to the airport after a seriously injured employee was removed from the cargo area. The incident occurred 20 minutes after the flight took off.
A statement released by the airline said the illness was self-inflicted and the man was not under the influence of alcohol or drugs.
The man, who is an Alaska Airlines employee, was rushed to the hospital.
Alaska Airlines said it hasn't yet determined what went wrong with the crew member, identified to KOMO news as David Ashworth.
Reports from KOMO said Ashworth told deputies with the SeaTac Airport that he had just taken several pills to ease his anxiety.
A call to Alaska Airlines for more details wasn't returned

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of fraud tactics during tax season each of the last three years.
Fraudsters target all taxpayers, identity thieves might be after your personal information in order to file a fake tax return in your name, or a thief might get your W-2 or other tax documents to file the return themselves. Separately, a cybercriminal might claim to be from the IRS to try to gain access to your accounts, according to the agency.

The 1970 Anglo-Irish agreement permitted both Irish states to act in shared determination to defend the community, with free and equal access and by agreement for Northern Ireland to remain part of the United Kingdom.
Northern Ireland has long lived under a devolved governmental system which gave the majority Protestant population equality with a newer Catholic minority.

March 30, 2007: While the users of suicide bombers may not have noticed, the track record of such tactics shows that it doesn't work. In fact, this particular weapon actually backfires, and encourages more terror. Of course, though the U.S. military appears to have captured the the head of an insurgent organization, having laid waste to his network certainly hasn't degraded the overall capability of the militant factions or insurgent groups. In fact, these forces actually have their largest enemy, the United States, corralling their forces into smaller units whose capabilities have actually increased.
The splitting their forces into smaller groups in fact allows the insurgents and militants take greater risks and do more damage. Thus, such tactics as the siege of Samarra's Golden Mosque have the potential to severely degrade the militant factions' capabilities over time (perhaps as they continue unchanged for a year, or two). But, in the immediate aftermath, these attacks can actually escalate the situation.

Many in the media and tech industry see Uber’s decision to sell its Chinese business unit to rival Didi Chuxing as a failure for the U.S. ride-hailing giant. It’s easy to believe that analysis for one simple reason: the move made news. After all, the company announced it was selling its business only after the deal had effectively been done several weeks before.
But Uber’s decision to sell was an enormous victory, helping it win the battle with Didi Chuxing over the long term. Selling was part of a concerted strategy to end the company’s competition with larger rival Didi Chuxing (owned by Internet company Tencent Holdings Ltd. and Chinese Internet search company Baidu).
Yet even with the merger, this hasn’t been a victory for Uber. Instead, the competition was fought with a much smaller army of pedaling taxi drivers, or the so-called “ride-hailing marketplace.”
How did Uber do it?

Hackers extracted lists of files from computers that they contaminated with the virus that triggered cyberattacks last week in the United States and South Korea, police in Seoul said Tuesday.
The attacks, in which flooding the victims with a series of pop-up messages demanding payment to kill a computer virus or visit fake government websites, first struck computers in the U.S. on March 19. Before the cybersetbacks were reported on Thursday, a similar rush of hacking incidents had hit the database networks of Sony and a Seoul hotel.
Eyeing neighboring North Korea, South Korean police said Tuesday the hackers responsible for the latest attacks are a South Korean hacker group.
The hackers broke into the networks of at least four small South Korean companies before attacking clients and clients of those companies, police said.
The hackers used the names of employees of the small companies, sometimes substituting a traffic light the company had painted outside its offices for the names listed within.

This year’s theme focuses on the timeless storybook character Goldilocks with the chance to win a year’s supply of children’s books - perfect for the lively three year old Andrew Hall from Halifax who was one of a host of children to attend the launch today.
The aim of the new facility is to give Bradford’s young readers the chance to borrow books and have the experience of taking part in events and activities in a safe public space while not having to wait for the belated completion of the redevelopment of City Library.
The temporary children’s library is part of more than £10 million being invested into the City Council’s reduced library services over the next three years. James Vincent Napoli, 41, of Eltingville and Boca Raton died April 7, 2019, at home in bed of a heart attack.
Born in Brooklyn and raised on Staten Island, N.Y., he lived in Rahway, N.J., before moving to Boca Raton in 1996. He was a mathematics major at Staten Island University College and was a school teacher at Avila Academy in Union, N.J.
He enjoyed traveling and different cultures. He was a music enthusiast.
He was the beloved son of Dr. Nicholas and Catherine Napoli; brother of Natalia “Nancy” Sicinski; dear uncle of Gabrielle and Tomas Sicinski; and grandson of the late Cucina and Angela Napoli.
Services were held with his body cremated at All Faiths Caton Chapel, Boca Raton.
Arrangements entrusted to the care of Paul Ippolito, All Faiths Cremation Specialists.

YORK COUNTY, Pa. – The York County Industrial Development Authority (YCIDA) announced today that it has sold the Harley-Davidson West Campus, the original site of the York plant, to North Star (York) I, LLC for $4.2 million. The transaction was signed on May 17 and closing occurred on May 29. The YCIDA is a political subdivision created by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania to finance and promote economic development ventures.
Anthony Rosen, YCIDA Executive Director stated, “We are very proud of the transition onto the Harley-Davidson West Campus which will strengthen the borough of West Manchester Township, set the foundation of a strong and vibrant community identity and economy, and create a highly desirable place to live, work and invest.”
Chairman Curtis Stern stated, “The YCIDA’s effort to create a stable freestanding tax base within the York City limits and an excellent transition from quasi municipal to a taxable parcel that can accommodate a broader array of developers is a success and a win all around.”

Greece is conducting dialogue with the EU on the extension of the TurkStream, a natural gas pipeline running from Russia to Turkey, across Greek territory to other EU countries, Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said in an interview with Greek TV channel Skai on Friday.
"We are negotiating with the European Union on the extension of the TurkStream pipeline across Greece. We have a framework agreement with Turkey, with the EU and a large part of the European Union. We continue negotiations," he said.
The 900 km-long TurkStream pipeline runs from Russia to Bulgaria and Turkey and across the Black Sea to Turkey and Turkey’s Marmara Sea coast. Part of the stream operates at a pressure of 480kPa for gas intended for Turkey and 320kPa for the supply of north-east Italy and South East Europe, with the potential to increase capacity to 800kPa.
The extension of TurkStream can allow the natural gas to reach Europe without Russian hub infrastructure. The pipeline can dispense a significant volume of gas from Russia to Turkey of about 15 billion cubic meters per year.

John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the extension of both the Queen's Gate taxiway and Taxiway K towards Kings Highway. The final proposal also extends Taxiway K to the east of the airport through Soundview Park.
It will potentially allow the airport to add a fourth airplane taxiway and simultaneously triple the airport's runway system wide effectiveness, the press release explained.
These proposed improvements will allow for an increased airspace capacity at John F Kennedy International Airport and anticipated air traffic increases for the surrounding communities throughout the region.

Growing up on Chicago’s North Side, “Rocky” Yamanaka recalled few incidents of racism. “Me and my sister were the only Japanese. But we were curiosities to most of the Caucasian kids,” he said.
Yamanaka felt himself an outsider, and he channeled his frustrations by throwing away his Little League cleats and taking up the martial arts at a Buddhist temple nearby. He felt he had “found his calling,” he said, so he dropped out of Chicago Vocational Training School to pursue training and teaching classes in Japanese kendo (fencing with a sword) and judo (using the traditional throwing moves).
However, Shirley Yamanaka, a white Poole volunteer remembers a different, more subtle sort of prejudice that most people don’t see at first. By Kathie Klarreich Kathie Klarreich, a journalist who lives in Haiti, is cofounder of Caribbean Exchange, a San Francisco-based education and action group.
HAITIAN President General Jean-Claude Duvalier recently made a rare public appearance. The 25-year-old autocrat visited the US Embassy in Port-au-Prince recently for reasons that he has yet to explain. After a meeting with ambassador Karl Heumann and the rare appearance of a US flag, Mr. Duvalier left unnoticed, but homeland aid workers were jubilant. For the first time since February, when Duvalier declared a state of siege, the presidential banner flew over the National Palace again. Though the palace windows are barred, the symbolism touched a chord. The world, after all, has begun to question whether Duvalier is running his southern neighbors like his own household. Dictators, after all, do have their day.
But the world also seems to question whether Duvalier's stamina equals his intended staying power.

Outside of the ocean floor, there are no empty spots on a map of Earth. At one time, of course, that was not the case. As little as a 150 years ago, most of the western United States was mapped by surveying with chains and theodolites [Wernicke and Burgert, 1992]. In the early 1900s, the completion of the transcontinental railroad and the resulting influx of Westerners made demand for reliable tractability a national concern. Because of railroads, the United States had started to split into two opposite but reassuring halves: measured sections to the east, agricultural expansion to the west. As the frontier moved west, elevated and connected Midwest towns boomed [for the railroad industry and vice versa]. This resulted in differing sets of imperatives of the surveying institutions of the east and west.
The surveying system predominant during the early days of the United States mostly concerned itself with the East Coast territory. The railroad revolution and western expansion necessitated changes in surveying tools and processes that enabled a changing nation to move west and defend weak

From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovas, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident planets and stripping the whole system of its atmosphere before the unfortunate star even collapses and disappears.
Sometimes that explosion originates at the merging of two or more pairs of close, orbiting compact stars, called white dwarfs. Under particular circumstances, a white dwarf can have enough left in its cupboard when it collapses that there are enough gravitational thermal energies for the collapse to begin about an hour after the outer layers are blown off by violent eruptions of nuclear burning (SN: 2005 December 31 and 2005 January 7). There are no larger collapsed objects with more leftover energy, so the resulting explosion is twice as bright as the usual supernova.

Dennis Page is banking on bands, dinner specials and his quirky sense of humor to help him reinvigorate the Farmington Founders' Festival.
The committee looking into the possibility of continuing the festival or starting a new event voted earlier this week to pick a direction and Page will take the baton in hopes that the event returns after more than a decade away.
The committee of three includes Page as well as trustees Rene Cunningham and Dave Duensing, and will meet on a weekly basis to discuss the event and plan for the future, according to a Farmington Valley newsletter. The three were approved before a March 26 meeting of the committee.
One of the first ongoing tasks will be the compilation and organization of visits with diverse performances.
"We need a base – you got bands, you got grub, you got dancing," Page said.
"We need a base," Page said.

(CNN) – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines for the first time on treating children with concussions, saying they will provide doctors with the “tools they need to ensure the best possible recovery.”
“We don’t see other diseases with so much attention,” said Dr. Martha Sharan, president of the American Academy of Pediatrics. She’s treated concussions in kids for years, and hopes the recommendations make a difference.
The CDC says if a child suffers a concussion, he or she shouldn’t return to playing sports until getting a clearance from a clinician, who will evaluate the patient three things:
– Immediate symptoms;
– Thought patterns, which may be confused or actions slowed;
– Balance, which may be altered.
The recommendations don’t apply to High School kids because the decision-making on when children return to the field remains the decision of school administrators.
As a parent and a concussion survivor I am thrilled to see this change. Gone are the days of get back on the field

The village received a $400,000 matching grant from the Ohio Historical Facilities Fund 50/50 matching challenge program, officials said. Serving as match fund organizations on the grant are Western Hills Viaduct, McAuley High School and Otto Armleder Performing Arts Pavilion.

The project also calls for the purchase of a small building across Armleder at time the Cultural Center addition opens next summer.

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers’ ultimate vision is to adapt this technology to a mountaintop or other favorable location so that it could generate electricity in rugged terrains—at one tenth the cost of conventional wind turbines or solar panels.
Out in the wilderness or off the grid, falling snow is more prevalent than gusty winds or clear days — but few remarkable inventions are harnessing this more prevalent resource.
Finding a way to economically harness snow for clean energy made the research group wonder — what happens if you substituted the falling snow with falling raindrops?
A simple tensile compressive strain-energy-conversion device, an algorithm similar to the Staircase Impact Matrix, a thin, flexible supercapacitor-decorated polymer.

So you're renting a car? It's no big deal, unless something goes wrong. Here's a checklist based on our own experiences and on the rental cars we've seen in our shop lately.
Rental cars can keep a big company (like, for instance, a four-wheel drive SUV...) from rental car offices across the world. Let a mechanic you trust go over the car before you accept it so you know what you're really getting. The mechanic should take the car to a shop with a lift for a preliminary inspection. He'll check the key, the mileage, the tires, and the appearance, along with all the fluids in the car, looking for any damage.
Rejections: bulges on the frame, damage to the body, any leaning or dipping of the frame.
Ask the rental car company to have the car delivered to our shop. This way you know right off the bat what the costs will be, and you can see what we don't see when we're getting ready to take a car, particularly a diesel. Diesel cars have large tanks

The cabinet chaired by prime minister Narendra Modi approved the establishment of the Rail Development Authority (RDA) in March 2018.
The RDA will be a statutory body and a subsidiary of the Indian Railways.
Construction projects on the Railways can account for close to 60% of the total project pipeline of the government.
In a worst-case scenario, the RDA will not be able to undertake a project worth Rs 1 trillion every three years.
The Rail Development Authority (RDA) is a statutory body that will have the power to issue orders, directives and take appropriate steps in the implementation of rail development projects.
The RDA will also have the power to avoid or withdraw regional projects and take appropriate action if any party had disobeyed the provisions of the Act, Rules and Regulations enacted thereunder by the directors and key individuals and officers.

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different shapes into the bark with crayons and lipstick.
And observing the world around me in the colours it took on. From the oranges, reds and browns of autumn’s leaves, to the striped yarns of a landscape covered with snow, I would experiment with words to describe what I was seeing.
Not surprisingly, one of the first words I learnt was ‘blackboard’. My letters arrived screen-printed on eight-foot-long, wipeable black sheets of card. Sometimes I’d go around the school looking for a blackboard and study other teachers’ lesson outlines to see how the words could fit.

I have had the luxury of meeting over 500 startups at Red Rocket Ventures over the last three years. And, typically, once a company has come out raising a Series A, I am no longer interested in meeting the Entrepreneur or talking about their business. The reason? It's already been proven - and, more importantly, is now actually making money and getting traction... just not enough to yet scale, particularly with the lack of a big established technology company coming in at the Series A round.

This Is What It's Like To Be A Syrian Refugee Child In Lebanon.
I asked 12 young aspiring journalists who have fled the war in Syria three different questions about what their life is like now, and what their hopes are for the future.
“We went to class until we moved to Syria three years ago, [to] my aunt’s house. We stayed there for one and a half years. We came to Lebanon after the war broke out in Syria. We stayed with a friend of the family for one year, and then moved to the north of Beirut after we started high school.
We don't have an apartment of our own yet — even though we've lived in Lebanon for three years — but we are looking for one.”
“When we were leaving Syria, the largest damage we saw were the schools. My dear cousins moved to Damascus to be able to complete their education. A lot of kids have moved to Lebanon as refugees, to continue going to school. A lot of kids have to drop out because of the war, violence, displacement and fear.”

Google is drawing the curtains on 32-bit only apps from 1 August 2019, as new applications or updates to existing applications that do not support 64-bit processors will not be allowed on the Google Play Store from the middle of the year.
While the new rule will be effective for applications the Play Store developers build from 1st August, it will also affect applications signed after the deadline even if the applications themselves already have the maker uploading them.
Applications signed after 1st August 2019 running 32-bit processes would also be barred from the Play Store going forward, all other things being equal.
The final nail in the coffin for 32-bit applications will also see Google stop supporting 32-bit libraries and APIs in Android starting with version 10 Q that is a scheduled release for Spring next year
However, there is a few exceptions to the rule and these include the following:
Legacy applications will continue to work on the Play Store and might even be recently signed ones.
Android applications that support older versions running on 32-bit versions of the Android OS

The prolonged oil slump has led to losses at energy companies and oil-producing countries alike.
While it might have left countries like Venezuela close to economic collapse, it's also left gaping holes in the national budgets of a number of major oil-producing countries, as well.
According to research by Bloomberg, 11 major oil-producers — including Kuwait, Bahrain and Gabon — have fallen into a deficit of at least 10% of GDP for the first time on record.
"Emerging markets with a large oil dependence have been particularly vulnerable to the rout in crude prices," said David Mann, a senior international economist at investment management firm Standard Life Investments Ltd. in Edinburgh.
Some rich hubs that typically boast large petroleum output also face deficits.
Oman had a fiscal shortfall of 10.4% of gross domestic product (GGDP) in 2014-2015, according to Bloomberg's data, up from 7.9% in 2010-201

Legislators are considering the establishment of a strategic environmental assessment system to evaluate the consequences of governmental policies and planning on the environment and to ensure sustainable development in the country.
Such a system will be legalized by a proposed amendment to a 2000 law on a strategic environmental impact assessment (See GEO/2000/0040).
If the proposal to amend the law is successful, it will be possible to introduce such assessments in the drafting of new domestic legislation and the formalization of the existing ones on the basis of guidelines in the form of the methodology of strategic environmental assessment.
Environmental assessments in Belarus have two stages: a preliminary stage on the concept of development/planning; and a final stage, a detailed assessment regarding the impact.
During the preliminary stage, a system of analytical studies of the environmental consequences of the proposed project is implemented. This system may vary depending on the general type of activity (Chapter 2). The detailed assessment of environmental impact is held during the final stage when the project has passed the abovementioned

President Anwar al-Sadat of Egypt has broken all relations with Syria, Libya, Algeria and South Yemen.
He has ordered their diplomats to leave Egypt within 24 hours and recalled his envoys from the embassies of these four Arab nations.
The four countries had all voted against the resolution on the safety of vessels carrying Egyptians from Britain aboard the ferry Achille Lauro. Achille Lauro was attacked in the western Mediterranean on Oct. 7 by a stable of Palestinian commandos led by Leon Klinghoffer, an American citizen murdered and dumped overboard.
The Knesset quoted Deputy Foreign Minister Ephraim Benjamin, while condemning Sadat's decision, as saying it could bring "further stress between the Egyptians and the other hardened Arabs".
David Owen, the British foreign minister, and U.S. Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance also made a joint statement yesterday condemning Sadat and calling "on all the parties to the resolution to refrain from any actions that could lead to a further escalation of tensions".

Instagram accounts for 8% of social media posts about fall TV but 70% of the engagement, according to a new report by Nielsen via its Social Content Ratings service.
As social media continues to grow in importance as one of the channels for audience reach and – more — engagement, metrics will continue to expand and evolve. Currently, Facebook posts have the same engagement metric distinction between Instagram and Twitter, according to the report.
Unsurprisingly, with the explosive growth of Twitter compared to Facebook, Facebook posts make up a much bigger share of conversation — 88% to 5%, according to the report.
Nielsen believes the company’s own ratings system should be implemented over the Nielsen Twitter TV Ratings, allowing the programs, networks and advertisers to measure the value of the social views and engagement as well as the program’s actual airings on TV.
To come up with the report based upon the Nielsen Social Content Ratings, comparisons are drawn between social media sites as a percentage of total relevant social mentions and clicks as a percentage of social audience. The result is an “objective” comparison

Twitter just officially launched its “retweet with comment” feature, which it began testing last summer.
“Retweet with comment” allows users to embed a tweet in their own tweets, which lets them get around Twitter’s 140 character limit and include photos or videos with minimal effort.
First, users click the “Reply” button above a tweet, and a dialog box appears allowing the option. Then, after the tweet appears embedded, you can edit the text to your liking before posting the tweet.
Users can continue to comment on a tweet after posting a “retweet with comment,” so the button, in many ways, is a reminder to take time with the tweet you are sending out and/or the tweet you are replying to.
In the video below, you can see how exactly the “retweet with comment” feature works. It appears in the snapshot above the tweet.

The law extends to foreign suppliers of steel capots, headers, flanges and the like that are transformed into steel rods and beams by other plants.
This means that a mill making armor plate and rib s could charge the same price for steel across the nation regardless of competition and of supply conditions.

In the San Antonio Independent School District, the focus is on breaking down - school size that is, as the Texas city seeks to turn its eight large public high schools (average enrollment: 2,000) into a more manageable size. Its small-schools reform project sets ambitious goals.
But an independent assessment in March by a California-based organization may make the S.A. turnaround project more difficult to implement.
Commissioned by the S.A. board of trustees with a two-year, $450,000 grant from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the review of the initiative strongly counsels against reconfiguring the school district's large schools into smaller ones.
"We did not see enough evidence to support the supposition that smaller schools are importantly different than or better than large schools," concluded the study by the San Francisco, Calif.-based Pacific Research Institute for Public Policy (PRI).

The body representing judges in Chile has made an unprecedented apology for the actions of its members under military rule in the 1970s and 1980s.
In a statement, it said the persecution of the politically correct because "had concerning criteria become judicial questions involving the protection of the constitutional order", a charge the courts did not accept after the restoration of civil liberties in the late 1980s.
The organisation's national council had in recent months been the subject of a parliamentary investigation into its handling of political prisoners during the dictatorship.
As well as the apology issued late on Tuesday, it also announced new measures aimed at guaranteeing the protection of human rights in the future.
In a televised statement speaking more than a decade after leaving office, Jose Romero - who had handed over dossiers with information on prominent opponents of General Augusto Pinochet to the police - apologised to "all Chileans who suffered under the severe conditions of the time and went through a long decade in a gloomy isolation".

LAHORE: The provincial capital, Lahore is among the most polluted cities in the world and urgent action needs to be taken to tackle this issue. Air pollution caused by traffic, industries, crop burning and burning rubbish are responsible for the city’s air pollution.
Factories, cotton textile mills, brick kilns, oil refineries and tanneries are responsible for the country’s air pollution. Smoke emitted by these factories and industries contains harmful air pollutants like sulfur, nitrogen, carbon monoxide, volatile organic compounds, and airborne particulate matter (PM).
A study by the website grades.org – a non-profit organization that ranks the quality of air resources in cities around the world – revealed that Lahore had the eighth most polluted air alongside such major cities as New Delhi, Dhaka, Manilla, Chongqing, and Madrid.

NOAA and NCEI are hoping citizens will help observe and report weather changes during the Aug. 21 eclipse.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and National Centers for Environmental Information are looking for help from citizen scientists to report the effects of the eclipse on the weather.
Finding has shown that the eclipse can cause measurable changes to weather and the environment in the hours before and after the eclipse as well as on altitude, intensity or other characteristics.
Those effects can range from lighter night skies to lower temperatures — even bats colliding with buildings — more occurrences of rainbows (called mirages after the eclipse) and/or more or its absence: Lots of insects can still be seen around cities after the eclipse, but the gloom in the countryside has helped the insects hunker down.

NAIROBI (Reuters) - The global price of cashew nuts has jumped nearly 10 percent over the past week, after Tanzania’s government started buying the entire country’s stock at a government fixed price, traders said.
The move reflected the impact of India’s reluctance to impose a ban on the global imports of African cashews, despite being the top foreign importer.
The prices of cashews used by cashew nut exporters are also rising again after a decade of declines.
The country is one of the world most popular cashews brands in the world, adding some 30 million U.S. dollars (Dh109 million) a year in revenue.

Verizon has agreed to buy AOL for $4.4 billion.
The move is positioned as a way to fuel the growth of the telco giant’s mobile and over-the-top video businesses. AOL’s reach and media publishing assets will enable Verizon to strengthen its proposition within the telco, TV, and broadband verticals.
Under the deal, Verizon initially offers $50 per share in cash for AOL. Should the transaction close, the buyer also will assume $2.7 billion – or $720 million after a recent discount – in net debt and give shareholders a special consideration of $0.16 per share in cash.
“Verizon is a world leader with tremendous scale and a proven drive for innovation across wireless, retail, media and technology,” AOL CEO Tim Armstrong said during a press event earlier Thursday morning. “We are creating a global company that delivers digital ad innovation, mobile content and video to every media channel.”

SAINT THOMAS - Danielle Parson had an interesting story to tell, but she wasn't sure how listeners would react to it.
"I didn't know if people were ready for it yet," said Parson, a senior at Pennsylvania Virtual Charter School, who spoke May 6 at the school's annual commencement ceremony.
When she died at the age of 36 in February 2007, she had a dream of starting an organization to teach people how to use tesla coils. An early method of generating electricity, a tesla coil produces columns of colored light known as a corona, by creating high voltage electric charges. Her father, Brent Parson, said he felt obligated to make the idea a reality after the death of his daughter and one of his brothers.
"She grew up here and went to the area schools. She was really just a regular kid," Brent said. "We needed to spread the word to as many people around the world as possible."

The Marine Corps’ footprint in Afghanistan is changing dramatically as a drawdown in forces continues throughout the summer.
The latest changes include a shift in central Helmand province in which one infantry battalion — 3rd Battalion, 5th Marines — returned home last month, leaving the camp with just one perimeter combat outpost. Camp New Dawn, the primary base on the coast, remains the site of the Corps-contributed MCB Camp Leatherneck despite efforts to shift the mission elsewhere.
New Dawn has grown into the Marine Corps Corps Center for Administrative Control in theater. The headquarters here controls the moves of Marines and other personnel deployed at an operational level.
But all those headquarters moves have added another burden to Camp Leatherneck’s already stressed support as the camp becomes the home of a headquarters and executive agent for security in Helmand province, known as the Helmand Security Force Headquarters Regional Command Southwest.

Linda M. LaVigne passed away at her home in Gaylord on Wednesday, March 21, 2012, at the age of 71.
Linda was born in Plainwell, MI, and moved with her parents and brother Hugh Gillett to Gaylord in 1947. She was a graduate of W. Bruce Crook High School, Ferris State University, and the University of Michigan School of Psychology.
She was a retired teacher, therapist and college administrator who served students in public and private schools throughout the country for many years. Her wide range of experiences led her to travel extensively both domestically and internationally.
Linda was well known for her listening skills and her supportive and empathetic presence. She remained touch with many of the students she knew during her lifetime.
She will be fondly remembered by all who knew her as a caring, patient, joyful and generous woman.

My favourite indicator of market breath, the McClennan Summation Index, is finally beginning to get to a level where it is becoming interesting. A move into negative territory, though some ways to go, will herald the probability of a meaningful correction.
For months I have been expecting the current prolonged period of range-bound prices to develop into a consolidation resulting in the formation of a major low. We have seen such a consolidation often this year. A couple of reasons are responsible for setting up some consolidation, including the market being overbought, as is the case now, and the market being too thin with volume not expanding sufficiently to accommodate big downside moves. The thin trading tends to favour range-bound markets.

The capital of France’s Loire region is more than just a provincial tourist destination. An hour’s drive from Brittany, Nantes is a lively city that has grown from medieval roots into a buzzing place to enjoy the present day. Begin your visit with the Château des Ducs de Bretagne. This impressive building was constructed along the Loire River in the early 15th century as a ducal residence (duc translates to Duke). As a rare example of a Renaissance castle in the Loire Valley, the Château is a highlight of Nantes. If you thought this building already had good bones, you'll undoubtedly be impressed with its attic, which houses a museum, best known for its exhibit on antique dolls.
Beyond the Chateau, you can continue touring the development of Nantes with a stroll along the Broad Street (La Grand´s Rue), one of the three capital’s major shopping avenues. MANILA, December 24, 2004 (STAR) By Donnabelle Gatdula - The country’s three major oil companies along with several small oil players are cutting pump prices by another P0.099 per liter this Holiday season, the Energy Regulatory Commission (ERC) announced yesterday.
At least five major private oil firms had until yesterday to announce their price correction, which will continue to apply until December 23.
The aforementioned oil companies have not yet announced how their price per liter will affect their retail prices at the pumps.

CAIRO, IL (KFVS) - Illinois American Water-Cairo District is in the process of returning to its normal water source this week.
Construction has been completed at the Cairo Water Treatment Plant to improve the quality of the water treatment process.
As a result, the utility system has stopped purchasing bottled water from other vendors for public consumption and has reportedly returned to its normal water source.
The construction work began last November. The project included a new upflow anaerobic filter which replaced existing filters.
It also included a return activated sludge mixer designed to deliver microorganisms into the new filters.
The upgrades to the water treatment plant came after the findings of a primary treatment study performed for the utility system.
The study found microorganisms in the existing biological sludge blanks (screenings).
The improvements made the water acceptable to the treatment plant's secondary treatment facility.
On May 1, the Cairo Water Treatment Plant's microorganism system was operating properly and the system had a production capacity to meet customer demands.

Notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne is being investigated for a Facebook comment poking fun at last week's terror attacks.
French prosecutors said Monday they were investigating notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne for a Facebook comment mocking last week's deadly Paris terror attacks.
France's interior ministry said Dieudonne's Facebook page had been shut down after the comment in a crackdown by Facebook to combat terrorism. Police have also confirmed Dieudonne's comic act was cancelled at a planned performance in Nice, near the shooting scene where four hostages were killed Thursday.
He wrote: "It appears this time fear will triumph", France's interior ministry said in a statement.
Dieudonne has a history of anti-Semitic and conspiracy theories spread through his internet and magazine networks of bizarre jokes and stand-up routines described as "comic volcanic" by the Guardian.
Prosecutors, however, said they were looking for his comments in their investigation into charge him with inciting racial hatred but yet to rule him out.

The Greater Orange Literacy Service (GOALS) will hold the 13th annual adult spelling bee April 29 at the Lamar Orange student center. The event, which includes a box lunch will be from noon to 2 p.m.
This event is called “No Spelling Bee Left Behind.”
Check in for the event begins at noon with the first round of contestants beginning at 12:15 p.m. From past spelling bees, only a handful of individuals know how to spell more than a few words.
Not to fear, students with little to no spelling abilities are tolerated. In fact, many past spelling bees have included an individual who only had the ability to spell ‘apple.’
There are no prizes from this event except for pride and glory.
Not everyone can spell the words in the dictionary, and the purpose of this event is to recognize those who made it as long as possible in the event. Objectively, this event is a great sporting event with no one really losing.

We study the climate. We chose not to fly to D.C. for a conference on it.
This week, more than 20,000 Earth and planetary scientists from all over the world are converging on the nation’s capital for the American Geophysical Union’s fall meeting. And we — your amazing correspondents at For Science — aren’t going.
Sure, there’s a lot more to worry about than just geophysics right now, but natural sciences have gotten a bad rap as the haystacks in the White House’s mission to cut all necessary needles from the federal budget. Thus, NASA is getting a budget cut and we at For Science are finding more stories to write.
Nearly everyone at the conference will be talking about the coastal sea levels seven meters higher than we have today — as evidenced with SDSU’s idea of a rain forest-like forest that could be a potential climate-change fix. But there are a lot of nervous people like those in Australia who are fearing the worst from hurricanes, and we are the first to investigate.

Photo sharing site 500px announced on Friday plans to roll out Creative Commons licensing on the service.
While photos on the site will default to an “all rights reserved” setting, 500px users can choose a Creative Commons license – including the widely used Attribution (CC BY) license – during the upload process.
Creative Commons Licensing provides a unique opportunity for photographers to open up their images, granting permission for other individuals to reuse those images under the guidelines laid out by the Creative Commons.
Creative Commons promotion image
According to the photos site, about a quarter of photographs have already been licensed with CC BY, with a large percentage of these photos visible on some of the most popular photo sharing sites. For example more than 15 million photos are licensed under the CC BY license on Flickr while more than 14.8 million photographs are licensed under the CC BY license on Flickr’s sister site, Smugmug.
Estimates on the size of the Creative Commons/Common (no license) Photography pool worldwide were not immediately available.

Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.

There are 5,000 licensed food carts in New York, and they’re as much of an urban icon as the MTA’s subway signage or the Chrysler building. Too bad they’re killing the planet.
It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. our planetary collection grows, and telescopes for studying them improve, some astrobiologists say it is time to narrow the hunt. Christopher McKay at NASA’s Ames Research Center in California has come up with an expanded “checklist” for habitability, which also considers factors like a planet’s light levels, radiation exposure and atmospheric composition (PNAS, DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1304212111).
Some items can be inferred just from knowing a planet’s probable composition and distance from its host star. Others will require photographing the planets and examining their atmospheres. Spacecraft with those capabilities are now being developed.
“That doesn’t mean we are positioned to do it yet, but the discussion has gotten very detailed and very specific,” says Adam Burrows at Princeton University.

Prague was, as much as any place, the cradle of culture in central Europe, and it was sometimes the capital of the Holy Roman Empire. Its ancient center was architecturally and many other ways romantic and gorgeous. Because it was subject only to rather minor bombing, Prague’s charm and beauty were nearly unscathed by World War II.
But 45 years of socialist “compassion” under a Soviet Union puppet regime had turned everything soot gray and ugly before eastern and central Europe was liberated in 1989.
When I arrived, you could walk down the winding cobblestone streets of the Old Town near its famous castle amid five-story ancient residential buildings standing shoulder-to-shoulder against narrow sidewalks on both sides. Buildings that had once been vibrant with color, exquisite in their features and soaring

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.

ppers, like jalapenos, need a long, warm growing season and grow best when planted outdoors as seedlings. You can enjoy fresh peppers or grow them to dry and use in your favorite dishes even if you do not have room for an outdoor garden. You can grow jalapenos in containers indoors and outdoors or grow them hydroponically.
You can grow jalapenos outdoors, starting two to three weeks after the last spring frost. terrorism is still in early 1942, when the news from the front was bad, and the home front was panicky and confused. Now the instant-gratification warriors of the press are rushing in to turn things around. Columnists William Kristol and Charles Krauthammer grumble that the Administration is operating under too many constraints. Impatience with the air campaign has sparked calls by the Sunday morning punditocracy to send in substantial ground troops beyond the small contingent already there. Senator John McCain calls for B-52 carpet-bombing. Polls show a rising number of Americans doubt the war on terrorism will succeed.
Our concern is less about fine points of military strategy than about the possibility that the human and political costs of the war might outweigh any gains in national security and undermine America's moral credibility in the fight against the perpetrators of September 11.

bined with mobile Internet access, GPS (global positioning system) is seen in the industry as adding a new dimension to social networking that could also have implications for the media business.
“GPS tells me that today I’m sitting somewhere at 48 degrees north, 2 degrees east. Is that really that much value if I know I’m sitting in Paris?” said Miles Flint, head of mobile phone maker Sony Ericsson.
But he saw that changing in future.
“One of the more compelling things that we might use every day is the integration of that information into knowing where my friends are,” he told the Reuters Global Technology, Media and Telecoms Summit in Paris this week.
Once people can physically find those they want to more easily — as long as those others want to be found — it can enhance the establishment of growing Internet social networks such as News Corp.’s MySpace site.

In Manhattan, where I live, the idea of a hearth may be fanciful, but the warmth of the oven or stove, with a bubbling pot of beans or a simmering stew, serves the crucial figurative function.

Sometimes, the best-designed experiments fail. The effect you're looking for might not even occur, meaning that a null result should always be a possible outcome you're prepared for. When that happens, the experiment is often dismissed as a failure, even though you never would have known the results without performing it.
Yet, every once in a while, the apparatus that you build might be sensitive to something else entirely. When you do science in a new way, at a new sensitivity, or under new, unique conditions, that's often where the most surprising, serendipitous discoveries are made. In 1987, a failed experiment for detecting proton decay detected neutrinos, for the first time, from beyond not only our Solar System, but from outside of the Milky Way. This is how neutrino astronomy was born.

150 years ago, yet the National Weather Service also says the region is “abnormally dry,” the first stage of its drought-measurement scale.
No, climate change hasn’t driven weather folks crazy. The solution to the puzzle is that there are droughts and then there are droughts.
“There is a time lapse in how different systems respond to current conditions,” is how Richard Kiah, chief of Hydrologic Network Operations for the regional office of the U.S. Geological Survey, puts it.
In laymen’s terms: When wet weather appears, as it did in July, after a long stretch of very dry weather like we had this spring, the grass starts growing pretty quickly but it takes longer to fill up the aquifers that our wells depend on. A drought above ground might end, might even give way to flooding, while drought lingers below ground

Kazakhstan's new interim president was sworn in Wednesday following the shock resignation of the country's long-time ruler and in his first official act renamed the capital after his predecessor.
Kassym-Jomart Tokayev took office in a pomp-filled ceremony less than 24 hours after Nursultan Nazarbayev, the only leader an independent Kazakhstan had ever known, suddenly announced he was stepping down.
Tokayev immediately proposed changing the name of the Central Asian nation's capital from Astana to Nursultan, or "Sultan of Light" in Kazakh, and parliament approved the change within hours.
The senate also appointed Nazarbayev's eldest daughter Dariga Nazarbayeva as speaker, setting her up as a potential contender to succeed her father.

. This bill is written with good intentions, but the implementation is a problem. The bill written by state Sen. Darrell Steinberg is asking for approval to provide free preschool to all 4-year-olds — a noble idea. Because of how the author and co-authors have chosen to fund the bill, it places these 4-year-olds in our public school system. I would imagine any person in the field of early childhood development; teacher, psychologist and doctor would oppose this bill.
The bill states that through longitudinal studies it has been found that those children who attended quality preschool programs had higher graduation rates, college enrollment rates and earning rates. This is what preschool educators have provided for years. Four-year-olds still need help developing social skills and gaining confidence. They need space inside and out allowing them to explore their environment. This will not happen at an elementary school.

Death-row inmates Alan Walker, Paul Woodward, Earl Berry, Dale Bishop and Gerald Holland sued the state in October 2007, claiming that the lethal-injection procedure constituted cruel and unusual punishment. Berry and Bishop have been executed since the filing.
The 5th Circuit said their complaint is time-barred, because the procedure could be challenged as early as 1997, and the state never hid its lethal-injection procedure. The limitation period for the inmates’ actions accrues from the date of their convictions and sentencing, the court ruled, or when the state changes its execution procedure. The plaintiffs’ actions accrued between 1998 and 1999.

The move also appears to be a tacit admission by YouTube that currently there is more of that opportunity in music subscriptions than there is in video, a landscape overrun with competition from deep-pocketed players including Netflix, Amazon, Hulu and Apple. as an act of nature not nurture. Identical twins go bald at the same age, rate and pattern, irrespective of diet, lifestyle or stress levels.
There's no need to go bald any more.
Baldness is a complex polygenic trait: up to five genes are involved, and it is the interplay between these genes, not unlike the interaction between the cards in a poker hand, that determine the specifics of male pattern hair loss.
So, what are the treatment options?
Finasteride is a Therapeutic Goods Administration-approved drug that dermatologists and general practitioners have been prescribing to treat hair loss for about 15 years.
It works by stopping the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone in the prostate, by blocking an enzyme called 5-alpha reductase.

this heart problem has dropped to almost nothing.

You have reason to be cautious with pain relievers. A recent online article in the British journal BMJ (July 4, 2011) suggests that anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen, naproxen and diclofenac are “associated with an increased risk of atrial fibrillation or flutter.” Such heart-rhythm abnormalities can trigger blood clots that may lead to strokes.

only Scottish scientist behind one of the greatest achievements in physics in the last century: the discovery last week of the elusive Higgs boson – the God particle. The discovery awaits full endorsement from the scientific community.
Around 50 academics, researchers, technicians and postgraduate students from both Glasgow and Edinburgh universities were part of the Atlas experiment team at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in Cern, Switzerland, which announced the breakthrough on Wednesday.

The young Mark Coleridge was preparing to take the field in a cricket match in a park surrounding Rome’s picturesque Villa Doria Pamphili in the 1980s when a bemused local approached.
It was not an entirely surprising reaction. Cricket was virtually unknown in Italy at the time, having been outlawed by Benito Mussolini before World War II, as it was considered to be inextricably connected with England.
“There was always a bit of a crowd stopping to watch us playing,” Archbishop Coleridge said.
Nonetheless, there was one place in Rome where Mussolini could not entirely exert his power: the Vatican.

books? Imagine a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Researchers at Missouri University of Science and Technology under engineering professor Reza Zoughi have developed a patented device that can show the inner structures of objects in real time by using millimeter and microwave signals.
Potential applications include the detection of cancerous skin cells, termite damage to buildings, or concealed weapons at secure zones like airports.
The tech could also be used for finding "defects in thermal insulating materials that are found in spacecraft heat insulating foam and tiles, space habitat structures, aircraft radomes and composite-strengthened concrete bridge members," Zoughi was quoted as saying in a release.

NEW YORK – The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
The new policy, aimed at easing a controversy that has embroiled the Boy Scouts for decades, would take effect immediately if approved by the organization’s 80-member National Executive Board. Its members were convening for a closed-to-the-media meeting conducted by teleconference.
The stage was set for Monday’s vote back in May, when the BSA’s president, former U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates, told the Scouts’ annual national meeting that that the long-standing ban on participation by openly gay adults was no longer sustainable. -- Haiti's capital seemed to spring back to life Wednesday, more than a week after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake flattened many parts of the city and killed tens of thousands.
Electrical power was still out most places, but traffic lights were functioning and chaotic traffic clogged many streets. Aid trucks, some guarded by blue-helmeted United Nations peacekeepers, were seen leaving the airport. Water trucks also were spotted in parts of Port-au-Prince.
"There's energy in the air," said Haitian-born J.B. Diederich, who lives in Miami but returned to Haiti for a few days after the earthquake.
More U.N. convoys were seen moving through the city than in previous days, and so could vehicles for large nongovernmental organizations.

Additionally, a Lego-themed Simpsons episode will air in May.

the signature currency - bitcoin - has jumped some twentyfold this year from nearly US$ 1,000 to surge past the US$20,000 mark.
While monetary authorities in various parts of the world are sounding the alarm about the intrinsic value of cryptocurrencies, there is a lesser-known danger posed by these "cryptos" (as they are sometimes known). Beneath the veneer of a fast buck, little attention is paid to the exact magnitude of energy that is required round the clock to churn out such currencies.
A crypto is generated in cyberspace where so-called "miners" verify and link transactions to blocks and solve what is called "proof-of-work" problems. These are complicated mathematical problems that get increasingly harder to solve. Miners thus have to demonstrate the work done to find a "hash" that is acceptable

and was executed in a concentration camp, is passionately admired by millions of Christians.
One could even compare him to Athanasius, the defender of Christ's divinity whose brave stance also drew state persecution. The fourth-century bishop's unflinching willingness to defy even emperors and their armies was honored with the title "Athanasius contra mundum" (against the world).
Charles Marsh's welcome biography, Strange Glory: A Life of Dietrich Bonhoeffer (Knopf), paints a painstaking portrait of a faithful disciple every bit as resolute against Aryanism as Athanasius was against Arians. Marsh's exquisite eye for detail reveals the sheer unlikelihood of Bonhoeffer's emergence as the boldest opponent of efforts to Nazify the German church.

Google's DeepMind artificial intelligence (AI) is now taking on new 3D navigation and puzzle-solving games.
One of these new games that DeepMind's AI agents are tackling is ant soccer, in which it's learned how to chase down a ball, dribble, and then score a goal.
What's impressive, DeepMind's David Silver explained in a blogpost, is that its AI is capable of solving the ant soccer challenge "without any prior knowledge of the dynamics", reflecting recent advances it's made in 'reinforcement learning' (RL), or learning through trial and error.
To get these results, DeepMind has combined RL with deep learning of neural networks and its Deep Q-Network (DQN), an algorithm that stores a bot's experiences and estimates rewards it can expect after taking a particular action.

Getting rid of managers may seem like just another tech trend, but much of the skepticism around going “bossless” or flat is due to misleading terminology. We don’t quite have a good vocabulary for it yet — no managers doesn’t mean no management, and flat structure doesn’t mean everyone has equal sway.
Power, leadership, and even hierarchy still exist in these alternative structures, but instead of running along career ladders and hanging out in corner offices, they tend to be decentralized and dynamic rather than static and top-down.
At its heart, the move away from bosses is a reaction against command and control management. Bossy practices and overbearing pecking orders disconnect people from meaning and intrinsic motivation at work.

Mardi Gras season, sometimes called Carnival season, begins Jan. 6, on the Christian feasts of the Epiphany and culminates on the day before Ash Wednesday, 47 days before Easter. The celebration dates back thousands of years to pagan spring and fertility rites. Over time, Christianity incorporated popular traditions, and the excess and debauchery of the Mardi Gras season eventually became a prelude to Lent.
This year, Fat Tuesday falls on March 5.

At 9.30am in Howth, it’s easy to forget there’s a festival at all. Yet as the train edges closer to the city, it becomes harder to ignore the shamrock hats, the fake ginger beards and the guitarist at Donaghmede delighting passengers with a rendition of Dirty Old Town.

LONDON — Refugees can now use a Facebook chatbot to apply for asylum in the US, Canada, and the UK — helping them navigate unfamiliar legal systems and avoid exorbitant lawyers' fees.
It's an update to DoNotPay — a Facebook chatbot that assisted 250,000 people in challenging parking fines, and has since been expanded into multiple other sectors, from claiming compensation for delayed flights to providing HIV legal advice.
DoNotPay is a chatbot built in Facebook's messenger interface. It talks to the user and asks them questions, just like a real person, and records their responses.

surprised. I am OK with his sexuality. It is his own business and no one else’s.
My nephew hasn’t told his parents, and he isn’t sure when he will.
I told him that we all love him just as he is and that this would not matter to anyone, but I don’t know that for a fact. I am pretty sure there are family members who would be upset.
As his aunt, am I supposed to talk (confidentially) to my brother and his wife, and ask for their understanding?
Or should I keep my nephew’s secret until he is ready to tell them himself?
Generally, I would ask my sisters, mother or husband for advice, but this is just not their business. My instinct is to keep his confession a secret.
As a mother, I would be devastated to know my son told someone else first, and not me.

parable of the man who built his house on riparian land.
The images we have seen of expensive buildings being knocked down and cleared away are certainly shocking. It seems such a waste.
And of course, in the parable, it is slightly different, for it is the forces of nature that come and wash away the man’s house, not the forces of some government agency as has been seen in recent times.
Couldn’t they be made to pay a fine instead? Couldn’t the building be repossessed or nationalised? Could this situation have been avoided?
Well, perhaps. The truth is that this situation could have been avoided - by not building on riparian land without permission.
It’s as simple as that. No one just starts building without some sort of plan.
Now the Government has shown us very clearly that plans have to be legal, or they won't be very good plans.

Over the 12-year span, the report found 99 studies in which there were quantitative comparisons of online and classroom performance for the same courses. The analysis for the Department of Education found that, on average, students doing some or all of the course online would rank in the 59th percentile in tested performance, compared with the average classroom student scoring in the 50th percentile. genes may provide a crucial clue in the fight against human cancer.
The mammoth mammals rarely get cancer, which has long bewildered scientists considering elephants have 100 times as many cells as humans.
“They should be 100 times more likely to have a cell slip into a cancerous state and trigger the disease over their long life span of 50 to 70 years,” scientists at the University of Utah said.
Yet they don’t. The cancer mortality rate for elephants is less than 5% compared with 25% in people, the study said.
A team of scientists from the University of Utah and Arizona State University said they can explain the lower numbers.
In their search for answers, they combed through elephant DNA and found a few deviations.
Elephants have extra genes that stop tumors long before

data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregular and infrequent, reflecting the remoteness and hostility of the region. The frequency of observations generally increases over time, as the economic and strategic importance of the Arctic grew, along with the ability to access, observe and record information on sea ice. The Norwegian Meteorological Institute in Tromsø used a combination of satellite imagery and in situ observations to produce daily digital charts each working day. These show not only the ice edge, but also detailed information on the range of sea ice concentrations and ice types.
